urn:contentItem:5BJT-0RM1-JD6G-435R-00000-00LETTER: Climate action2014-02-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:43:36ZLexisNexisLETTERSLETTER: Climate action

EDITOR: Further to your front page story (Cooma swelters in hottest, driest Summer in years Express February 6) and as local fire crews have just mopped up after the Murrumbucca fire, it is worth considering what the Climate Institute had to say about bushfire risk.

Bushfire risk is rising. Between 1973 and 2010, the Forest Fire Danger Index rose at 16 out of 38 weather stations around the country.

No station recorded a fall. Most of the most severe fire seasons have occurred from the 1990s. The number of days of very high to extreme fire danger in NSW could more than double from the current average of 17 days per year to 38 by 2050, by which time, Victorians could face the prospect of a 'Black Saturday' every two or three years.

The Climate Institute goes on to say that, while fuel loading is an important factor in the risk of fire, weather conditions including drought, high winds and extreme temperatures are often a major influence. According to the Institute, climate change doesn't light fires, but by rendering southern Australia drier and hotter, it's creating favourable conditions for more dangerous, more frequent bushfires. The Bureau of Meteorology's observations show that, since the 1970s, fire danger has been rising in many parts of the country. The average temperature of the continent has risen by almost a degree since Federation, while rainfall in the south has fallen.

The mix of warmer and drier weather is raising the risk of severe, extreme and catastrophic fire weather conditions in southeastern Australia.

Because the fire season itself is spreading further into spring and autumn, there are fewer and fewer opportunities for authorities to conduct hazard-reduction burns. With this in mind, it is critical that we pull out all stops to mitigate further climate change.

These past weeks should be a warning to us all.

We need stronger action on climate change, not total dismantling of all climate policies by the Abbott government.

Jenny Goldie

President

Climate Action Monaro

Michelago

urn:contentItem:5HTP-6761-JD3N-51FM-00000-00'Drying climate' increases chance of deadly bushfires2016-01-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:43:36ZLexisNexisTHENATIONPg. 4'Drying climate' increases chance of deadly bushfiresPAIGE TAYLOR VICTORIA LAURIE, Additional reporting JOE KELLY, EXCLUSIVE

A dramatic decline in rainfall and slowing stream flows have combined to make a deadly bushfire much more likely in the forests south of Perth, according to the principal research scientist for the West Australian government department responsible for managing fuel loads.

Lachlan McCaw, from the WA Department of Parks and Wildlife, said fire-prone seasons in the state's southwest were starting earlier and lasting longer into autumn.

The fatal blaze sparked by lightning at Lane Pool Reserve last Wednesday had last night burnt out more than 73,000ha, and is the second massive bushfire to take hold in the region in 11 months.

On Saturday, the remains of two men in their 70s were found in separate houses in Yarloop, the old mill town 123km south of Perth that took the brunt of the fire late on Thursday.

"We've recorded a 10 to 20 per cent decline in average southwest rainfall in the last 25 or so years, but what that has led to is a much larger decline in stream flow of up to 50 per cent, and the underground water -tables are dropping as a result of less rain," Dr McCaw said.

"Our drying climate is certainly a contributing factor to increased fires. We may need to rethink our land use planning regarding people wanting to have houses in the bush. And it's certainly making the job of fire suppression much harder." Liberal senator and former chief executive of the Bush Fires Board of Western Australia, Chris Back, said increasing numbers of people living in areas of risk left governments with a higher duty of care.

"We need to return to the principles of prevention and not be focusing so much on the response in managing, in the past fortnight, bushfires," Senator Back said.

He warned that the lessons of the 2009 Black Saturday fires in Victoria had not been learned and said most of the 15 recommendations of the subsequent Senate inquiry into bushfire management in Australia had been ignored.

Since the Northcliffe forest fire that burned through WA's southwest for more than a week last February, the Barnett government has stepped up its program of prescribed burns in the region.

Using an extar $20 million for a four-year program of controlled burning, the Department of Parks and Wildlife has conducted 131,000ha of "cool burns" in southwest forests since July last year, a marked increase on recent years.The Barnett government has faced scrutiny over the response to the fire that hit Yarloop. There were about 200 firefighters on duty at the height of the blaze. On Saturday, 60 firefighters and five paramedics arrived from NSW to help, but the Baird government was not asked to send two firefighting aircraft, including a DC10 that can drop 45,000 tonnes of retardant at once.

urn:contentItem:5KNY-6J01-F0JP-W11D-00000-00Backlash on fires puts heat on firm2016-09-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:43:36ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. 11Backlash on fires puts heat on firmNivell Rayda Jakarta

Indonesia will investigate a local subsidiary of one of the world's largest paper companies amid suspicions it illegally occupied a protected peatland area.

The Environment Ministry and the Peatland Restoration Agency yesterday summoned executives from Riau Andalan Pulp and Paper, a subsidiary of Singapore-based Asia Pacific Resources International Holdings, and scrutinised a permit it acquired in 2009 to open a plantation in Pedang Island, east of Sumatra.

Ministry secretary-general Bam-bang Hendroyono said that during the closed-doors meeting the company had agreed to suspend activities on the island -immediately until an investigation was completed. No sanction had been imposed and the probe should take no longer than three months, he said.

After the meeting, RAPP president director Tony Wenas said his company "supports the government's commitment to restore peatland areas" and would accept any recommendation from the investigation.

The meeting came after officials from the restoration -agency, led by agency chief Nazir Foead, were denied entry to the concession area on Monday.

Mr Foead said agency officials planned to "conduct a spot check to see the conditions first- hand" after allegations the company was trying to open a new plantation on peatland supposedly protected by law.

He said officials had found -canals suspected of having been built to drain water from the peatland and prepare it for a plantation. Officials planned to measure the depth of the peatland, which is protected if it is deeper than 3m.

In a video released by the restoration agency, Mr Foead is seen arguing with a plantation security guard who also claimed to be a member of the army's special forces commando, Kopassus. The military has denied the guard was one of its own.

RAPP has said there was a misunderstanding, and it had -always been open to government inspections.

Last week seven officials -investigating a forest fire inside a palm oil concession area in -Sumatra were taken hostage by a mob who threatened to kill them unless they erased photographs and removed a sign advising that the area was sealed and under -investigation.

They were released unharmed after 12 hours when police intervened, but their cars and cameras were seized by the mob. The government believed the 100-strong mob was hired by the firm operating the concession, Andika Permata Sawit -Lestarian, an allegation the company has denied.

National police chief Tito Karnavian said police were -investigating both cases. "Obstructing government -officials from carrying out their duties is a criminal offence," he told the newspaper Tempo.

Environment Minister Siti Nurbaya Bakar condemned the incidents, promising to "wage war against forest and land fires".

President Joko Widodo has pledged more protection for the country's carbon-rich peatland areas. In January, he established an agency to restore about two million hectares of peatlands -destroyed in forest and land fires.

Scientists estimated more than 75 per cent of fires last year occurred on peatlands, some set deliberately to clear land for plantations, causing record catastrophic smoke levels affecting more than 500,000 people in -Indonesia, Malaysia and Singapore.This year, better responses and better weather have prevented fires reaching such levels.

urn:contentItem:5FBR-P6J1-JCMN-Y0G3-00000-00Scientists Measure Bat Populations In Post Wildfire Habitats2015-02-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:43:36ZLexisNexisScientists Measure Bat Populations In Post Wildfire HabitatsSamantha Richardson

Feb 20, 2015( International Business Times Australia: http://au.ibtimes.com Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Bats are highly important to our ecosystem as they help pollinate plants, contribute to reforestation and help maintain balance.

Due to these benefits, two NAU researchers, forestry professor Carol Chambers and graduate student Erin Saunders, began tracking bats in 2011 in the Ponderosa pine forests situated in eastern Arizona. The forest experienced the largest Wallow fire, losing nearly 849 square miles to it.<nl/> Since Arizona houses nearly 28 species of bats, these scientists were keen on understanding the effects of forest fire on the bats. They wanted to learn of their reaction to the post fire environment. The press release[1] disclosed that bats are indicator species that can predict an environmental problem. Hence, they can still provide information to the forest service employees on several matters post fire.<nl/> Maternity colonies have nearly 900 bats, and these contributed in the research as well. They roost mostly on tall or dying trees. Researchers state that this is an important bit of information for the forest officials as it would help decide which burned tress should be removed.<nl/> Chambers and Saunders used tiny radio transmitters for their research. They tracked the bats and compared different habitats based on the basis of the fire and the degree of loss in the ecosystem. Though they found that the fire did not affect the habitat of the bats, the researchers say that more fires and climate change will result in a decrease in habitat. <nl/> They also found that different bats prefer different habitats in terms of the severity of the burned areas. Some prefer unburned snags or areas where there are less trees lost to the fire. They also found that bat count decreased in both severely burned sites and those not heavily affected. Chambers and Saunders state that this could be due to the migration of the bats to other areas.<nl/> "Fire-killed snags usually fall within 10 years and it can take hundreds of years to regrow Ponderosa pine, if they grow back at all," said Chambers, referring to the consequences the bats would face in the long run. Saunders believes that the short term research must continue to provide stronger land management recommendations.<nl/> For questions/comments regarding the article, you may email the writer at samrichardson.ibtimes@gmail.com;<nl/> [ 1]: http://news.nau.edu/nau-scientists-measure-bat-populations-post-wildfire-habitats/#.VONdTyuUeSo

urn:contentItem:7W6C-WCS0-YBDY-R29M-00000-00IN BRIEF2009-07-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:43:36ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 24IN BRIEF

Tiny vow

THE tiny island nation of Tuvalu, under threat from rising seas caused by global warming, has vowed to fuel its economy entirely from renewable sources by 2020, joining 10 other nations.

Aquino ill

THE condition of former Philippine president Corazon Aquino, 76, in hospital for colon cancer, has deteriorated, her daughter Kristina said yesterday. She said Ms Aquino, 76, was in pain ``so please pray for her''.

Airline alert

HOLIDAYMAKERS may be turned away at airport check-ins if they have swine flu symptoms, Britain's two major airlines said yesterday. Virgin Atlantic and British Airways said sick passengers could be banned if they appeared ill.

Vote call

IRAN'S popular former president Mohammed Khatami has called for a referendum on the legitimacy of the government to end the post-election crisis. His call came as the last British embassy staff member among a group of nine arrested was released on $125,000 bail yesterday for inciting protests.

Fire threat

ABOUT 11,000 residents threatened by a forest fire in British Columbia have been evacuated, Canadian officials said yesterday. Firefighters were attacking the 3.5sq km blaze raging 275km east of Vancouver. At least three homes were destroyed.

Overseas News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>ASIA: SMOG-GENERATING FIRES SPREAD IN INDONESIA</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">- PAPER INDON HAZE (CARRIED EARLIER)    SINGAPORE, March 5 Reuters - New land and forest fires similar<br/> to those that blanketed the region with smog last year are breaking out in Indonesia and parts of Malaysia, the Straits Times newspaper said today.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Quoting officials in Singapore and Indonesia, the paper said new fires were spotted on the Indonesian island of Sumatra, the situation in East Kalimantan on the Indonesian part of Borneo island was becoming worse, and fresh fires were spotted in East Malaysia on Borneo.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The paper quoted Lim Hock, director of Singapore's Centre for Remote Imaging, Sensing and Processing, as saying "some very significant smoke plumes" had been seen in Sumatra.</p><p>Another Singapore official said the situation in Sumatra was worrying, although smog, or haze as regional officials prefer to call it, was still largely in the areas where the fires were burning.</p><p> "But towards the end of March and particularly April, we may see some hazy days here," he said.</p><p> In East Kalimantan, the situation was "desperate", according to the head of a German-Indonesian project to develop a forest fire management system.</p><p> The Straits Times quoted Ludwig Schindler, head of the Integrated Forest Fire Management Project, as saying: "It has gone beyond control. Only the rains can put them out now, so they are concentrating on containing the fires … to keep them from spreading."</p><p> The spread of fires in Borneo and Sumatra has Southeast Asians bracing for the possible return of the smog that smothered much of the region last year.</p><p> The fires, caused by slash and burn farming and plantation clearing and compounded by drought, spread a thick blanket of smog over parts of Indonesia, Malaysia and Singapore for several months and reached into Thailand and the Philippines.</p><p> They caused health problems, closed airports, posed a hazard to navigation and slashed the region's money-spinning tourism arrivals.</p><p>REUTERS shb</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1998</dc:source><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-02-28</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="330"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1998 AAP Information Services Pty. Pg. 9</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Blazing row over sackings;<br/>Prom fire allegations</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>MILANDA ROUT, environment reporter</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">UP to 220 firefighters were sacked by the State Government before the botched Wilsons Promontory fire, according to an expert report.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Government officials scrambled unsuccessfully to rehire the seasonal firefighters when the Prom fire jumped containment lines and burnt 6000ha, it is alleged.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The report, compiled by independent bushfire specialist group Forest Fire Victoria on its own initiative to generate debate, reviewed the Alpine 2003 bushfires as well as the Wilsons Promontory fire.</p><p>Co-author Athol Hodgson, who boasts more than 50 years' fire experience and was the state's chief fire officer, believes cost-cutting prompted the sackings.</p><p>He said the number of seasonal firefighters dropped from 600 in mid-January to about 380 by the end of March.</p><p>"And this happened when the DSE were engaged in a rather large autumn-prescribed burning, including Wilsons Promontory," Mr Hodgson said.</p><p>Natural resource expert Barrie Dexter, who helped compile the report, said the authors believed the DSE tried to rehire the firefighters when the weather became hotter and the Prom fire broke containment lines.</p><p>He said attempts to correct the "serious shortfall" in available firefighters failed.</p><p>Mr Dexter said it highlighted the lack of resources for fighting fires.</p><p>However, a spokesman for Environment Minister John Thwaites said the State Government had increased funding for firefighting by an extra $168 million in last year's budget.</p><p>He said this included 200 full-time fire specialists, with 90 already working.</p><p>"In the past year the Government has almost doubled the amount of fuel-reduction burning that has taken place compared to previous years," the spokesman said.</p><p>The Hodgson-Dexter report said authorities did not effectively patrol the burn-off at the Prom before it got of control.</p><p>"Parks Victoria and the DSE didn't learn any lessons from the Alpine fires," Mr Hodgson said. "They didn't put enough resources on it quick enough."</p><p>The 76-page report, titled The Facts Behind the Fire, argued that the Government's initial response to the Alpine 2003 bushfires was a failure.</p><p>The review called for a radical overhaul of the Government's bushfire management, saying that bureaucrats in too many different departments had hindered firefighting.</p><p>Creating one authority to deal with management of forests and bushfires would be the best way forward, the authors argue.</p><p>This would include the dumping of Parks Victoria and VicForests in favour of a revamped DSE.</p><p>Mr Hodgson said Forest Fire Victoria decided to conduct the review following its concerns with the Esplin inquiry into the 2003 bushfires.</p><p>The report has been given to Mr Thwaites, Opposition Leader Robert Doyle and the Emergency Services Commissioner for the coming Wilsons Promontory inquiry.</p><p>Editorial, Page 20</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5P2W-D3R1-F0J6-J4PT-00000-00'Big dry' points to active, early fire season2017-07-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:43:36ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 8'Big dry' points to active, early fire seasonPeter Hannam Environment editor

Weather patterns delivering an exceptionally dry winter across south-eastern Australia show little sign of breaking up, heightening concerns the coming fire season will be an early and active one.

Fire authorities won't formally release predictions for spring and summer until September. Wet periods in autumn, though, curbed hazard-reduction burning in NSW and Victoria.

"The next four to six weeks are going to be very important," said Ben Shepherd, an inspector and head of media at the NSW Rural Fire Service.

"Many of the agencies are looking for that opportunity to get out there and start those [hazard-reduction] burns again in earnest" before conditions turn too windy and warm, he said.

Authorities stress significant rain could yet push fire risks for the coming season back towards more typical levels, but note there is little sign of such a development.

High-pressure systems have dominated southern Australia, nudging rain-bearing systems south of the continent.

Saturday offered a clear illustration of the set-up. The bureau predicted almost the entire mainland of Australia would be dry.

The skies have been clear with an unusually wide daily temperature range over many regions. Nights were marked by heavy frosts or cold making way for milder than average days.

Big dry

Barring some unexpected instability, July will join last month as among Australia's driest.

Nationally, last month was the second-driest June since standard data began in 1910 with rainfall barely a third of average, the Bureau of Meteorology said.

Victoria had its driest June, NSW was the driest in 15 years and the Murray Darling Basin posted its lowest rainfall totals since 1986. "It very much seems to be centring on the border between Victoria and NSW," Richard Thornton, chief executive of the Bushfire and Natural Hazards Cooperative Research Centre, said of the rainfall deficits. Winter-to-date rainfall levels have been "very much below average" for most of southern Australia, bureau data shows.

Back foot

Fire authorities are keen to take advantage of the cool and dry conditions to ramp up controlled burns before windy and warmer days make such activities more risky.

Cyclone Debbie's aftermath brought heavy rain to much of the east coast in April, reducing opportunities for hazard-reduction burning. "That really put us on the back foot," Mr Shepherd said. In a typical year about 56 per cent of controlled burns in NSW are conducted in autumn and 23 per cent in spring.

During autumn, the RFS treated 93,116 hectares to protect 23,171 properties. By area, the tally was less than half the previous autumn's 191,684 hectares involving 27,867 properties.

"The wet winter and spring conditions proved difficult, however our prioritisation of burns based on risk has resulted in the statewide risk being maintained at 2015-16 levels," said Stephanie Rotarangi, of Forest Fire Management Victoria.

Longer-term trends

The key influence behind this year's relatively dry winter is far to the south. A positive phase in the so-called Southern Annular Mode marks a poleward contraction of the westerly winds belt towards Antarctica.

As the bureau notes, such a phase marked the Millennium drought during the "big dry" from 1997-2010. High-pressure systems that would normally sit further north track across more southerly parts of Australia blocking rain-bearing cold fronts.

In June, average mean sea level pressure readings were at record highs for many parts of southern Australia, including all but one site in South Australia and all but three in Victoria.

As the bureau noted: "Mean sea level pressure over southern Australia has been increasing in winter over recent decades. This pattern is consistent with future climate change projections for the Australian region."

Dr Thornton, of the Hazards CRC, said that along with trends towards drier winters for southern Australia, warmer-than-average temperatures during July to September are also the new norm.

"It's almost locked in to have above-average temperatures from climate change," he said.

The bureau will update its three-month outlook this week. The agency said odds were strongly pointing to a drier-than-usual July to September for much of the south of the country.

urn:contentItem:5HBP-M761-JD34-V1H8-00000-00New fire danger warning system tested to pinpoint risks2015-11-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:43:36ZLexisNexisBLUE MTNS RHPPg. 11New fire danger warning system tested to pinpoint risksPeter Hannam

Communities and firefighters could soon receive real-time warnings of risks from bushfires down to a matter of kilometres, according to a new model being tested this fire season.

As fire crews across south-east Australia prepare for an unusually active bushfire season amid an abnormally warm spring and an intensifying El Nino, researchers hope technological advances will soon give communities real-time information on the probability of fire threats down to a resolution of a few kilometres.

"People want to know: It's a fire danger, but a fire danger to what?" says Ross Bradstock, director of the Centre for Environmental Risk Management of Bushfires at the University of Wollongong, and one of the developers of the new model.

"It incorporates the probability of a fire starting and spreading, based on the fuel and the terrain, and it reaching property," Professor Bradstock said. "The warning system can be tailored to parts of towns or even suburbs."

The current warning system, modified after the 2009 Black Saturday bushfires in Victoria to include a "catastrophic" threat level, has been based on the McArthur Forest Fire Danger Index first developed in the 1960s. That method, however, is based only on weather, such as temperature, relative humidity and wind speed.

The variables included in the National Fire Danger Rating System Probabilistic Framework range from fuel load and its type, the nature of the terrain and the housing density in a particular region.

A prototypehas been tested in the Sydney region including the Blue Mountains. Further testing will continue in NSW this fire season, with the findings to date published by the Bushfire and Natural Hazards Cooperative Research Centre.

"You can have a region with a lower fire rating but have a particular location with a higher risk," Trent Penman, a bushfire behaviour specialist at the University of Melbourne, and another developer of the new model. "For people in those properties to know they are at higher risk would be beneficial for their preparations."

Richard Thornton, chief executive of the Bushfire and Natural Hazards CRC, said the existing fire danger rating system had been largely unchanged since the 1960s and a new fire danger rating system was a national priority "underpinned by the best science available".

The work is being coordinated by the federal Attorney-General's Department and involves state and territory emergency services, the Bureau of Meteorology, CSIRO, and several universities.

The new system could take two or three years before it is routine, and a key issue will be how the information is communicated to the public.

While avoiding confusion will be a challenge, the more specific warning may also result in greater involvement from residents.

"With fire management, you want individuals to respond to what is a community problem," Professor Tolhurst said. - The Sydney Morning Herald.

urn:contentItem:5SWD-4K31-F0JP-W3FS-00000-00Deadly inferno traps families2018-07-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:43:36ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 18Deadly inferno traps familiesSTAFF WRITERS, AFP

RESCUE crews are searching through charred homes and cars for those still missing after the deadliest wildfires to hit Greece in decades devastated coastal areas near Athens, killing at least 79 people and forcing thousands to flee.

There was no official indication as to how many people might be missing, and some took to social media and Greek television stations with appeals for information on their loved ones.

The death toll was expected to increase as crews searched more of the areas affected by the fires.

More than 280 firefighters were still in the area to the northeast of Athens in the wider Rafina area, dousing the remaining flames to prevent flare-ups.

A further 200 firefighters backed up by a water-dropping helicopter were tackling the second forest fire west of the capital, near Agioi Theodori, where local authorities pre-emptively evacuated three nearby communities.

Flags across Greece were flying at half-mast after the Prime Minister declared three days of national mourning for the victims.

The two fires on either side of the Greek capital started Monday within hours of each other, and were fanned by gale-force winds that hampered firefighting efforts.

The speed with which the fire northeast of Athens spread took many by surprise, and is believed to have contributed to the high death toll.

"We couldn't see any fire. The fire came suddenly. There was so much wind, we didn't realise how it happened," said Anna Kiriazova, 56, who survived with her husband by shutting themselves in their house instead of trying to run through the flames.

Ms Kiriazova said they doused their house in the Mati area near Rafina with water from a garden hose, and credited the fact that their window frames were metal instead of wood for their home being spared.

"We shut ourselves in the house, we closed the shutters, we had towels over our faces," she said.

"The inferno lasted about an hour. I have no words to describe what we lived through." Her 65-year-old husband, Theodoros Christopoulos, said the couple decided to take shelter in their home because the narrow roads outside were jammed with cars.

"There was a great panic because the whole street was blocked by cars," Mr Christopoulos said.

"Shouting, hysteria, they could see the fire was coming with the wind. It already smelled a lot, the sky was black overhead and in no time at all the fire was here." Hundreds of others abandoned cars and fled to nearby beaches, from where they were evacuated hours later by coast guard and private boats.

Dozens swam out to sea despite rough weather to escape the intense heat and choking smoke blanketing the area.

Some 26 men, women and children made it almost as far at the gated staircase leading down to the Greek coastline and the safety of water. In the end, they simply couldn't see it.

Greek authorities found a desperate huddle of bodies just a few steps away from the path to safety.

But the onrushing wall of smoke and flame at first blinded them, then choked them.

Their charred bodies, burnt-out cars, a few molten belongings - and the fire-blasted pine trees around them - are all that remains.

The charred bodies of the 26 people, including small children, were discovered at a villa at the seaside resort of Mati, 40km northeast of Athens, said rescuer Vassilis Andriopoulos.

They were huddled together in small groups, "perhaps families, friends or strangers, entwined in a last attempt to protect themselves as they tried to reach the sea", he said.

Elsewhere, bodies were recovered from the sea, where victims had fled in vain to escape the flames and smoke.

The intense wind had whipped fireballs into the sea itself.

Dozens of people were overtaken by the flames in their homes, on foot or in their cars. News photographers saw the burnt bodies of humans and dogs.

Out of a total 187 people hospitalised, 82 including almost a dozen children were still being treated, 10 of whom were in "serious condition", the fire services said.

According to the mayor of Marathon, Ilias Psinakis, about 3000 homes have been destroyed by the blaze at the seaside resorts of Mati and Rafina. One of them was his own.

Greece is in mourning with local mayor Rafinas-Pikermi telling media he expects the number of victims will 'be three digits'.

"Today, Greece is in mourning," said Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras, who cut short a visit to Bosnia and announced three days of national mourning.

Greek media described the disaster as a "national tragedy".

The Government has not yet said how many people were regarded as missing. But the death toll is likely to surpass that from the blazes which hit Greece's southern island of Evia in 2007 in which 77 people perished.

It's believed no Australians have been hurt in the fires.A Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade spokesman said the Australian Embassy in Athens had confirmed with local authorities no Australians have yet been reported injured or missing.

urn:contentItem:5CGC-N551-JD6G-41FB-00000-00Donation assists Aviation Brigade2014-06-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:43:36ZLexisNexisCOMMUNITYDonation assists Aviation Brigade

THE Cootamundra Rural Fire Service Aviation Brigade has received a boost to the tune of $2300 courtesy of a Lions Club wood raffle.

As a relatively new brigade with limited members and only $72 in the bank, the Cootamundra Lions Club came to the rescue of this branch of the Rural Fire Service when they offered proceeds of their wood raffle.

Funds will go towards some of the miscellaneous costs associated with the running of the brigade that are not covered by the RFS.

Brigade members put their hands up to sell the tickets, diligently manning stalls for three weeks all day Thursday and Friday and on Saturday mornings. Special mention must go to Bruce Smith and Bryan Gawthrop who gave a great deal of their personal time.

The Aviation Brigade formed around three years ago with a group of volunteers putting up their hands to be part of the support service.

They are based at the airport during bushfires assisting with refuelling of retardant. They were formally recognised as a brigade in 2013.

During the course of their time together, members have worked loading fire-bombing aircraft at major blazes across NSW including last year's Stockinbingal fire, the Blue Mountains fires when they were based at Albion Park, the state forest fire at Scone in NSW, last summer's fires around Wagga and the 2012 fire between Jugiong and Yass.

The RFS Zone Management Team has supported and encouraged the brigade with equipment and a new headquarters, as has Cootamundra Shire Council.

It is miscellaneous items aimed at the welfare of volunteers and accounting equipment that is not typically funded by the RFS. As such this donation will certainly come in handy.

Aviation Brigade captain John Ashcroft paid tribute to Lions for their support.

'Thanks to Lions Club's consideration and generosity, the brigade is now in a positive position to move into the next fire season much more confidently,' Mr Ashcroft said.

Lions Club member Eric Thorburn said it is the principle of Lions to supply wood, tickets and advertising materials to worthy organisations in an effort to help them fundraise.

The wood is collected by Lions Club members.

The load of wood was won by Mrs Marion of Cootamundra.

urn:contentItem:7XPB-5MK1-2PW5-F0H0-00000-00Tas: Fire burns close to central highlands towns2010-02-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:43:36ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSTas: Fire burns close to central highlands townsHOBART Feb 2

  Tasmanian firefighters are battling a large bushfire burning near the central highland Tasmanian towns of Wayatinah and Ouse.
   Hot northeast winds expected later on Tuesday will push the 3400ha Florentine state forest fire closer to the towns.


   Fires are also affecting towns on the west coast.
   Firefighters were taking advantage of cooler conditions early on Tuesday before temperatures in the low 30s arrived mid-afternoon, Tasmania Fire Service station officer Michael Goldsmith said.
   The fire started on Sunday and may have been deliberately lit.
   "The fire is quite large, there are also three spot fires and it is burning in close proximity to Wayatinah and Ouse," he told AAP.
   "The mild weather allowed crews to work late into the evening last night strengthening containment lines around the fire and utilising helicopters for water bombing.
   "We are not expecting spotting in those towns but there will be thick smoke and smoke will also affect Fentonbury, Westaway and Ellendale."
   The fire has not yet hit any houses or buildings but has destroyed power poles and substations owned by Aurora and Transend, Mr Goldsmith said.
   The fire may affect Wayatinah, Ouse and Ellendale within a few hours.
   High temperatures are expected to continue until Thursday afternoon.

urn:contentItem:803J-MVH1-2RG7-20TW-00000-00Waller apologises for Black Saturday failings2010-08-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:43:36ZLexisNexisWaller apologises for Black Saturday failings

Victoria's forest fire chief Ewan Waller has apologised for his failings on Black Saturday.

The Department of Sustainability and Environment (DSE) chief fire officer was criticised in the Bushfire Royal Commission's final report, which pointed to "deficiencies of leadership" across the state.

Former police chief commissioner Christine Nixon resigned from her role as the head of the Victorian Bushfire Reconstruction and Recovery Authority and former CFA chief Russell Rees has also resigned.

Speaking publicly for the first time since the report's release, Mr Waller defended the level of leadership shown on the day but said he ultimately accepted the Commission's findings.

"I fully accept the statements made about me in the Royal Commission," he said. "I believe they're fair and reasonable.

"I'm fully accountable and responsible for my actions on the day and I will never step away from that.

"Certainly I'm very sorry for the people affected by the bushfires and if [there is] anything I did that aggravated that situation I fully accept that."

Mr Waller says he never considered quitting his post.

"I do want to continue," he said.

"I've offered to the Government to continue in my role because I believe I have something to significantly add, particularly in this really critical burning program, preparedness and that continuity angle."

urn:contentItem:5SR7-JW21-JCM0-602D-00000-00Woodchip proposal in southern Tasmanian raises questions over truck routes, forestry deals2018-07-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:43:36ZLexisNexisWoodchip proposal in southern Tasmanian raises questions over truck routes, forestry dealsBy state political reporters Alexandra Humphries and Ellen Coulter

A draft development application for a woodchip export facility near Dover reveals there would be truck movements every five minutes between Judbury and Strathblane 10 hours a day, six days a week.

In November, Southwood Fibre, which is part of the Neville-Smith Forest Products Group, announced plans for a $42 million woodchip export facility at Strathblane.

That proposal has since raised concerns among some local community members and salmon giant Tassal, which has a nearby lease.

Right to Information (RTI) documents obtained by the Tasmanian Greens showed a series of emails between Sustainable Timber Tasmania (STT, the state-owned forestry business) and Southwood Fibre, which Franklin MP Rosalie Woodruff said indicates "active collusion" between the State Government and the proponents.

The Greens also obtained the November version of a 500-page development application for the project, which has not yet been fully submitted to the Huon Valley Council for consideration.

The application revealed there would be an expected 13 truck movements per hour both ways between Strathblane and Judbury if the operation ran 10 hours a day, six days a week.

There would also be 800 additional truck movements per week delivering wood to Southwood for chipping.

The documents showed timber would initially come from plantations but would include wood residues in the medium term.

A new road would also be needed to avoid incursions into the World Heritage Area because the middle of Peak Rivulet Road, which would otherwise be the preferred route, is the border of the World Heritage Area.

An email within the correspondence sent to STT from a redacted email address said: "we need a new road with a new name, it can be metres from the existing road if need be".

Resources Minister Guy Barnett said the contents of the RTI obtained by the Greens included only correspondence between STT and Southwood Fibre that was necessary to provide landowner consent for the project.

"This is just another kooky conspiracy theory cooked up by the Greens to try and remain relevant with their base," he said.

Questions over dealings around plantation forest 'fire sale'

Proponent James Neville-Smith also denied any connection between his project and Reliance Forest Fibre, which last September purchased state-owned plantation forests for the price of $60.7 million.

ASIC documents showed Reliance Forest Fibre was established just two months before the purchase of the plantations and had a parent company in the Cayman Islands.

At the time, Labor branded the deal as a "fire sale" and the Greens named it a "dud deal" with both estimating the trees were worth millions more.

However, the RTI documents showed the general manager of Reliance Forest Fibre, whose name was redacted, was involved in email correspondence with STT about the Southwood Fibre woodchip export proposal as recently as late May, at one point inquiring how "our new proposal" for changes to the road network was going.

Southwood Fibre's James Neville Smith said the general manager of Reliance Forest Fibre was Danny Peet, a former employee of Neville Smith Forest Products who was finishing up business but had used his new email address.

Mr Peet remains listed as the general manager of Neville Smith Forest Products' SmartFibre, according to the SmartFibre website.

Mr Neville-Smith said neither he nor any associates nor any members of his family had had any financial interests in Reliance Forest Fibre or their forestry funds.

Ms Woodruff asked Premier Will Hodgman during Parliament whether the sale of the plantations to Reliance Forest Fibre included a deal that a southern export port would be established.

A government spokesman said the plantation sale was not based on the establishment of a southern port, and due process was followed during the sale.

Resources Minister Guy Barnett was also asked in budget estimates hearings last week whether harvesting of the plantations bought by Reliance Forest Fibre was reliant on a southern export solution, to which Mr Barnett responded it was a question for STT or Reliance Forest Fibre.

He was then asked whether the Government had suggested the Strathblane site to Neville Smith Forest Products but Mr Barnett said he would not go into personal details or commercial in confidence discussions.

Calls for transparency

The Wilderness Society said the leaked information demonstrated that the Government was "well and truly involved" with the woodchip mill proposal.

"It begs the question exactly what conditions, exactly what assurances did Reliance Forest Fibre get from the Government when they bought this plantations about this dover woodchip port."

He is also concerned about the intentions to use native forests and the impact of increased truck traffic.

"This proposal demonstrates that there are going to be hundreds of truck movements every day crossing the Huon Highway, 288 trucks a day will be crossing the Huon Highway 24/7," he said.

Far South Future Group, which is fighting the proposal, described the revelations as disturbing.

"We call on Labor now to stand up to the Liberals on this, to not tolerate this lack of transparency and utter disregard for the community of Dover and far south Tasmania," said president Rachael Trueman.

"The potential for job losses in the industries of aquaculture and tourism is enormous and the community is not being considered in this issue."

urn:contentItem:5VJR-K761-DY19-C501-00000-00Wind and lightning fuel flames, towns remain under threat2019-03-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:43:36ZLexisNexisWind and lightning fuel flames, towns remain under threatMelissa Cunningham, Liam Mannix and Simone Fox Koob

Firefighters have worked through the night in tough conditions battling 19 raging bushfires in Victoria's east with strong winds fuelling flames and lightning strikes sparking news blazes.

Firefighters have worked through the night in tough conditions battling 19 raging bushfires in Victoria's east with strong winds fuelling flames and lightning strikes sparking news blazes.

More than 2000 firefighters remain on the ground fighting the fires which stretch from Melbourne's south-eastern fringe to Victoria's alpine region.

"There were strong winds, pretty dry conditions and fresh fires starting as result of lightning strikes late yesterday throughout the state," Country Fire Authority incident controller Ben Rankin told ABC Radio.

"There is active wind forecast today and what we are finding is that even when the conditions are benign it doesn't take a lot of breeze for these fires to run quite intensely."

Lightning ignited 11 new fires on Monday evening including seven north of Orbost and another four near Dinner Plain in the state's Alpine region, Mr Rankin said.

Two firefighting taskforces have already flown in from NSW to help Victorian firefighters battle the bushfires, and another three taskforces from South Australia are due to arrive on Tuesday.

"We're hoping we'll have really good conditions today," Mr Rankin said.

"Some of our firefighters have been working for weeks and weeks on these large fires in Gippsland and we'll be continuing to monitor activity on each of these fires today and adjust community safety warnings as we need to."

The fires have already destroyed at least nine properties, but authorities are expecting to uncover many more property losses once they are able to better access the burnt areas on Tuesday.

Fires were bearing down on the town of Dargo, in East Gippsland, on Monday but an emergency warning was downgraded about 5.30pm allaying fears two fires near the town would merge into one large blaze.

Rainfall also eased the fire threat in some areas overnight.

Towns and properties across the east of Victoria are likely to be threatened this week as unpredictable weather fuels the flames.

Multiple watch-and-act alerts remain in place including in Yinnar South, Gembrook, Lincola and Dargo where fires are not yet under control.

At 6pm on Monday, the bushfires crossed the urban boundary and Dandenong South residents were warned to take shelter immediately as flames burned through grasslands in Bangholme.

Firefighters managed to gain control of that blaze within an hour.

Throughout Monday, Victorians were on edge as emergency alerts swung from evacuation messages to notices stating that it was too late to leave.

The status of some fires was downgraded, but almost none have been declared under control yet.

Emergency Services Commissioner Andrew Crisp said on Monday it was going to be a challenging week for firefighters across the state.

"We know that these conditions will continue for the next couple of days. We will then see some further milder weather for the state as a whole and possibly some rain on Wednesday. But we can't afford to become complacent," he said.

"Unless you've got a really, really good reason to be there - please just stay away from fire affected areas."

THANK YOU TO ALL THE EMERGENCY SERVICES, YOU GUYS ROCK!! Just a quick note to let people know that it has been a...

Posted by Dargo River Inn on   Sunday, 3 March 2019

Similarly , a 17,000 hectare fire north-west of Valencia Creek also improved slightly after light rain fell on some parts of the blaze.

Firefighters were braced for a severe thunderstorm that could roll over Gippsland and produce more lightning and spark new blazes.

At least seven properties have been destroyed in the huge Bunyip State Park blaze, and at least another two were lost in the Yinnar bushfire.

Warnings for the two fires were also downgraded on Monday.

The Bunyip fire rolled south through more than 12,000 hectares over the weekend and through several hamlets including Tonimbuk, destroying several homes. On Sunday night, a wind change pushed the fire north and back on itself.

Other major fires burning in the state included a 17,000-hectare blaze in Licola, in the state's east, where embers and ash were blowing around the hamlet.

In Wilsons Promontory, south-east of Melbourne, 3000 people have been evacuated. The popular national park will be closed to campers for the upcoming Labour Day long weekend due to a growing bushfire in the hills.

Dozens of schools and childcare centres across the state's east were closed on Monday, with many due to remain shut on Tuesday.

Health alerts have also been issued, with smoke from the bushfires contributing to poor air quality in Gippsland and the Latrobe Valley. Air quality in Morwell South and Churchill was classified "unhealthy for all groups".

Both Mayor Graeme Moore and Andrew Clarke, owner of Jinks Creek Winery, said they believed the fire's ferocity was due to the government's failure to sufficiently backburn the Bunyip State Park.

Mr Clarke said he had been "on the government's back for ages" to burn nearby land. Cr Moore said state and federal planning overlays prevented the council from doing it themselves

A Forest Fire Management Victoria spokesman said the department was "burning smarter, rather than focusing on a number of hectares target. In some areas, this may mean less planned burns - in other areas it may mean more".

However, the organisation admitted that no planned burns had been done recently due to "unfavourable weather conditions".

Police confirmed the worst for teacher Elke Frank. Her family's 32-year-old home was destroyed by the Yinnar South blaze.

Ms Frank was able to grab a bag pre-packed with videos, photo albums and documents on her way out on Saturday night, but she didn't think it would be the last time she would see her house.

Later that night, Ms Frank's son saw photos on Facebook showing their home had been gutted.

"It was a shock," Ms Frank said. "It's just a pile of black rubble??? There's nothing there."

Police then called on Sunday afternoon confirming the loss.

Ms Frank said it was heartbreaking for her, her partner and her three children to lose decades' worth of memories and belongings.

"My partner had more than 2000 books he'd collected. My son had just moved back so he had all this stuff. They're all devastated," she said.

"We were always just hoping it wasn't going to happen."

- With Sophie Aubrey

urn:contentItem:5H3D-YC81-F0JP-W53Y-00000-00Bushfire locals warned of more homes likely to be lost2015-10-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:43:36ZLexisNexisTHENATIONPg. 5Bushfire locals warned of more homes likely to be lostSUE NEALES RURAL REPORTER

Several houses were destroyed and two fire crews narrowly -escaped injury as a large bushfire near the central Victorian town of Lancefield continued to burn out of control yesterday.

Fanned by fierce southeast winds, the fate of dozens of homes surrounded by thick tinder-dry bush was last night unknown as the escaped planned burn-off threatened to reach farmland near Baynton and Pastoria East on the fire's northwest rim.

Country Fire Authority operations chief Euan Ferguson warned that the Cobaw fire was likely to rage for at least another two days, with the number of houses already destroyed around Benloch and Cobaw expected to rise.

Mr Ferguson said 220 fire crews were working hard to -contain the difficult forest fire -before a return to hotter weather and strong north winds late -tomorrow, which could threaten to blow the fire back on Lancefield. "We are doing our best but this fire has many tongues and is burning in forest gullies that are very dry and hard to reach; it is reasonable to expect there will be more property losses," Mr Ferguson said.

Anger in the local community at the unnecessary and deliberate nature of the fire spilt over yesterday at a community meeting held in Lancefield, 70km north of Melbourne.

Local Environment and Lands Department representative Alan Goodwin faced heated questions after the state government admitted the massive bushfire that has burnt more than 3000ha of bush and scrub started when a controlled burn escaped.

Victorian Premier Daniel -Andrews yesterday ordered an -independent inquiry into how the fuel-reduction burn was planned, why it was started at a time when weather forecasters predicted scorching heat and strong winds in following days, and how it broke containment lines.

But Mr Goodwin denied the fuel-reduction burn in the Cobaw state forest, west of Lancefield, had at any time been left unattended, unwatched or inadequately controlled, despite the AFL grand final public holiday in Victoria last Friday and the next day's match.

"I know our (planned) burn was responsible for this (fire) but there were people right through the burn controlling it, including overnight," Mr Goodwin said, as those at the meeting heckled and jeered him.

Local outrage has also focused on the refusal of police manning seven roadblocks to let residents back into fire areas to see if their houses are still standing.

One mother told the meeting that she had fled her home in the Benloch forest area on Tuesday with her two -babies and now feared she was left with nothing because officials refused to tell her if her house had been spared.A neighbour was able to assure her that the house was untouched and her goats were alive.

urn:contentItem:5K0Y-T651-JD3N-50TR-00000-00Conversations2016-06-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:43:36ZLexisNexisFEEDBACKPg. 18Conversations

Flogging a dead horse Everyone knows all this, why flog a dead horse ("Commuters urged to take a selfie during their nightmare commute and send a message to Canberra", whittlesealeader. com.au, June 7)?

We have a great public transport system. It did me when I used to work in St Kilda back in (the) 1970s. I had to catch two trains then.

margaret box, via Facebook

Not everyone can use it Great public transport? My daughter, to get from Doreen to Reservoir High School, nearly two hours by bus. Disgusting.

Not everyone can use public transport.

Tradies, for instance, cannot lug tools in a pull-along case. sharron knights, via Facebook

Build roads before estates Maybe if the roads suited all the estates they put in up High St and Plenty and Bridge Inn roads, Mernda, people wouldn't be so impatient. They know how many houses are going in, yet the roads can't cope. People lose their minds with all the traffic they sit in day and night. Roads should be developed before estates.

elaine turnbull, via Facebook

Benefits of more trains For every extra train you put onto a line in peak, you take 1000 cars off the road benefiting train and car journeys.

Imagine putting 90 new trains an hour on - 90,000 less cars per hour. And you could do that spending one-tenth that the East West Link was going to cost.

Ninety trains equals $1.8 billion, not $18 billion-. Ninety thousand less cars equals 270km less traffic jams an hour.

jo, via whittlesealeader.com.au

Use public transport What about using the public transport system- and keeping off the roads? You're already subsidising the transport system, so you might as well. Or, what about picking up a local co-worker and thus keeping another vehicle off the road?

terry, via whittlesealeader.com.au

Try to live closer to work I DON'T have a nightmare commute. I live close to work and work close to home. Maybe the people working in Broadmeadows, living in Werribee or going from Westgarth to Burwood each day need to re-evaluate their living or work arrangements.

Life is full of sacrifices and we live in a city of over four million - what do you expect? The problem isn't transport infrastructure, the problem is people either living too far from their jobs and that too many jobs are centralised in and around the city.

timmy, via whittlesealeader.com.au

Thanks for co-operation I WANT to thank communities across Melbourne, particularly those in the northern suburbs, for your co-operation while 13 planned burns were completed during autumn.

The burns were successfully conducted by crews from Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning (DELWP), Parks Victoria and the CFA.

Smoke from these burns was highly visible and some road closures were needed to ensure the safety of motorists and our fire fighters - and we appreciate your understanding during those times.

Residents and business owners do provide valuable input into our decision making about bushfire management.

We thank those who've contributed and encourage more of you to get involved by talking with our forest fire management staff at your local DELWP or Parks Victoria office, or by phoning us on 9210 9222.BRYAN WELCH, DELWP Port Phillip region- assistant chief fire officer

urn:contentItem:5NT7-VGW1-JD34-V2TR-00000-00Phantom's influence can't be masked2017-06-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:43:36ZLexisNexisWEEKENDERPhantom's influence can't be masked

One of the earliest exhibitions at the new Newcastle Region Art Gallery in 1977 was Ghost Who Walks Never Can Die, a Pop Art inspired show in which a large group of artists, including Richard Larter, Garry Shead, Phillipe Mora and Martin Sharp, focused their creative energy on the popular comic book character, The Phantom.

The Phantom, (Ghost who walks) was created by American cartoonist Lee Falk over 80 years ago, a few years after his hugely successful Mandrake the Magician hit the news-stands and three years before Bob Kane's Batman scaled the skyscrapers of Gotham City. Although the world's first crime fighter to don a figure-hugging body-suit came from Bengalla, (the fictitious African/Indian country not the coal mine) he was an instant planetary success. In Australia, The Phantom is the longest-running comic in publication. It is the only country where the 1996 movie adaptation was not a commercial flop.

Forty years after the original exhibition one of the artists from that show, Peter Kingston, has joined once more with local popular culture guru and fellow Phantom devotee Dietmar Lederwasch to bring together the work of over 50 artists for the ever-evolving The Phantom Show at the Newcastle Art Gallery. It is testimony to The Phantom's ongoing appeal to artists and public alike that there are now more than 200 pieces in this exhibition.

Local artists are major contributors to the project, including Michael Bell, Dallas Bray, Chris Capper, Dino Consalvo, James Drinkwater, Ron Hartree, Aleta Lederwasch, Dietmar Lederwasch, Claire Martin, John Morris, Lezlie Tilley, Peter Tilley, John Turier and Graham Wilson. They have applied their individual styles and approaches to create a complex, largely light-hearted and joyful exhibition of super-heroic adventure interlaced with snippets of domestic life, contemporary politics, erotica and re-assessment of the central character's position in a post-colonial world.

Hamilton's Gallery 139 and Acrux Gallery have combined to present Little, two wide-reaching exhibitions of small paintings, prints, ceramics, drawings, photographs and sculptural pieces from a large group of local artists at differing stages of their careers. Many young and emerging artists are represented, with their work hanging comfortably beside those of well-known artists such Vera Zulumovski, Edward Milan, Malcolm Sands, John Earle and Catherine Di Gravio. Despite the diminutive nature of the individual pieces these are two successful exhibitions where imaginative hanging gives every piece the space required to engage with the audience.

In Bennett Street, Hamilton, is Newcastle's newest commercial gallery, Studio 21. It is owned by artist and designer Maryanne Walmsley, who also has work in the Little show. Her latest group exhibition Light/Weight introduces new artists to the local exhibition scene along with works from Gallery 139's owner Ahn Wells and Acrux director Nadia Aurisch. Such mutually supportive collaboration between independent galleries helps to energise the sector for the benefit of artists, collectors and the public by developing expanding networks and encouraging increased interaction with the broader community.

If you are visiting Sydney, head to Paddington and take in the exhibitions from two of Newcastle's most prolific and progressive painters.

In Sydney A-Bridged at Janet Clayton Gallery, Dino Consalvo breathes new life into familiar images, exploring the bridges that span the city's harbour and rivers from new perspectives, reducing the engineered landscape into boldly constructed, energetic paintings balanced by a calm and harmonious tonal palette.

Just around the corner, the window of the Olsen Gallery is ablaze with a massive forest fire from Peter Gardiner's exhibition Apotheosis.

But, inside, the heat becomes an inferno of Dante proportions as the whole world burns. From observing lightning strikes and solitary, giant burning trees set against undefined old-world backgrounds and modernist houses exploding in a fire-ball, the viewer is engulfed by the awe-inspiring conflagration which seems to roar and fill the space with smoke.

Apotheosis is undoubtedly Gardiner's highpoint, so far.

urn:contentItem:5NT7-VGW1-JD34-V3DR-00000-00Phantom's influence can't be masked2017-06-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:43:36ZLexisNexisPhantom's influence can't be masked

One of the earliest exhibitions at the new Newcastle Region Art Gallery in 1977 was Ghost Who Walks Never Can Die, a Pop Art inspired show in which a large group of artists, including Richard Larter, Garry Shead, Phillipe Mora and Martin Sharp, focused their creative energy on the popular comic book character, The Phantom.

The Phantom, (Ghost who walks) was created by American cartoonist Lee Falk over 80 years ago, a few years after his hugely successful Mandrake the Magician hit the news-stands and three years before Bob Kane's Batman scaled the skyscrapers of Gotham City. Although the world's first crime fighter to don a figure-hugging body-suit came from Bengalla, (the fictitious African/Indian country not the coal mine) he was an instant planetary success. In Australia, The Phantom is the longest-running comic in publication. It is the only country where the 1996 movie adaptation was not a commercial flop.

Forty years after the original exhibition one of the artists from that show, Peter Kingston, has joined once more with local popular culture guru and fellow Phantom devotee Dietmar Lederwasch to bring together the work of over 50 artists for the ever-evolving The Phantom Show at the Newcastle Art Gallery. It is testimony to The Phantom's ongoing appeal to artists and public alike that there are now more than 200 pieces in this exhibition.

Local artists are major contributors to the project, including Michael Bell, Dallas Bray, Chris Capper, Dino Consalvo, James Drinkwater, Ron Hartree, Aleta Lederwasch, Dietmar Lederwasch, Claire Martin, John Morris, Lezlie Tilley, Peter Tilley, John Turier and Graham Wilson. They have applied their individual styles and approaches to create a complex, largely light-hearted and joyful exhibition of super-heroic adventure interlaced with snippets of domestic life, contemporary politics, erotica and re-assessment of the central character's position in a post-colonial world.

Hamilton's Gallery 139 and Acrux Gallery have combined to present Little, two wide-reaching exhibitions of small paintings, prints, ceramics, drawings, photographs and sculptural pieces from a large group of local artists at differing stages of their careers. Many young and emerging artists are represented, with their work hanging comfortably beside those of well-known artists such Vera Zulumovski, Edward Milan, Malcolm Sands, John Earle and Catherine Di Gravio. Despite the diminutive nature of the individual pieces these are two successful exhibitions where imaginative hanging gives every piece the space required to engage with the audience.

In Bennett Street, Hamilton, is Newcastle's newest commercial gallery, Studio 21. It is owned by artist and designer Maryanne Walmsley, who also has work in the Little show. Her latest group exhibition Light/Weight introduces new artists to the local exhibition scene along with works from Gallery 139's owner Ahn Wells and Acrux director Nadia Aurisch. Such mutually supportive collaboration between independent galleries helps to energise the sector for the benefit of artists, collectors and the public by developing expanding networks and encouraging increased interaction with the broader community.

If you are visiting Sydney, head to Paddington and take in the exhibitions from two of Newcastle's most prolific and progressive painters.

In Sydney A-Bridged at Janet Clayton Gallery, Dino Consalvo breathes new life into familiar images, exploring the bridges that span the city's harbour and rivers from new perspectives, reducing the engineered landscape into boldly constructed, energetic paintings balanced by a calm and harmonious tonal palette.

Just around the corner, the window of the Olsen Gallery is ablaze with a massive forest fire from Peter Gardiner's exhibition Apotheosis.

But, inside, the heat becomes an inferno of Dante proportions as the whole world burns. From observing lightning strikes and solitary, giant burning trees set against undefined old-world backgrounds and modernist houses exploding in a fire-ball, the viewer is engulfed by the awe-inspiring conflagration which seems to roar and fill the space with smoke.

Apotheosis is undoubtedly Gardiner's highpoint, so far.

urn:contentItem:574Y-CM61-JCM0-60KS-00000-00Firefighters control park blaze2012-11-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:43:36ZLexisNexisFirefighters control park blaze

Firefighters in Victoria's Mallee have managed to contain a fire that has been burning in the Murray Sunset National Park.

The blaze was spotted by crews about 6:30pm (AEDT) last night and was quickly controlled using firefighting aircraft.

The Department of Sustainability and Environment's (DSE) Nathan Christian says the fire was one of several sparked by this week's lighting strikes.

He says crews will continue to check to see whether any more fires are active in the region.

"We're hoping with these fires that we've got today, we're hoping to declare safe in preparation for tomorrow's weather," he said.

"Tomorrow's weather [for] the Mallee, if not extreme, it'll be at the upper level of the severe fire danger rating."

Authorities says they will continue with reconnaissance flights in the Wimmera and Mallee today to see whether this week's lightning strikes have started any more fires.

The weather bureau predicts temperatures will be in the low to mid 40s before a cool change reaches the region on Friday.

The DSE's Lee Gleeson says firefighters are preparing for hot conditions forecast for tomorrow.

"The conditions across especially the northern parts of the northern Wimmera are in the severe range which is [a] forest fire danger of over 50," he said.

"So that says to us that any fire that does start may be difficult to contain, especially in the earlier stages, so we'll be looking at a very quick attack on any outbreak of fire.

"After lunch in the heat of the day, we'll put a flight up out of Horsham.

"It will transverse across the district, especially the northern end around the Little Desert and the West Wimmera, to see if lightning strikes from Monday have created a fire and if there are, we'll be on them quickly."

urn:contentItem:5SJW-53F1-JD34-V0KD-00000-00'I want to work... for my community': refugee hopes to be first Karen police officer2018-06-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:43:36ZLexisNexisSATURDAYPg. 4'I want to work... for my community': refugee hopes to be first Karen police officerElspeth Kernebone

Myo Chit Oo wants to be the first Karen policeman in Bendigo.

When he succeeds, he may even be the first Karen policeman in Australia.

And he's well on track. Last week, Mr Oo found out has been accepted as a forest fire officer trainee with the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning.

He is the first to do this in Bendigo's Karen community.

Mr Oo came to Bendigo four years ago aged 13, with his parents, two sisters and brother. Before this he had only ever known life in a refugee camp.

When he came to Australia, Mr Oo had only ever known life in a refugee camp. He was born in the Thai camp, where his parents had lived for about 20 years after fleeing violence in Myanmar.

Initially, life in Australia was tough. Mr Oo spoke little English, and had left behind many good friends in the camp.

However, during his four years in Australia he has been able to learn English, make friends, and settle into school life.

Having recently finished year 12 at Weeroona College, Mr Oo is now studying at Bendigo Tafe.

"Sometimes I miss some of my friends when I first came here to Australia, but now it's ok," Mr Oo said.

"I like to be in Australia because we have more freedom here, but if we stay in refugee camp, we don't have the opportunity to get more education."

Karen people originate from the Kayin state in Myanmar, formerly Burma. The people group is ethnically diverse, and does not share a common language culture or religion.

Many have been forced to flee in the face of violence from a military state.

The first Karen people came to Bendigo in 2007.

By 2015, there were at least 1,000 Karen people living in Bendigo.

Now, settlement service caseworker Nay Chee Aung estimates there are at least 2,000 people in the city's Karen community.

His job with the Bendigo Community Health Service is to work with people who have recently come to Australia, doing casework, running a youth group and connecting people to services.

He began work with the service as a volunteer, seeking to better connect his community with services.

Bendigo is a fantastic place for refugees to settle, according to Mr Aung.

"Bendigo is very welcoming," Mr Aung said.

"Bendigo does a great job for new families. People are constantly working on it to make it more welcoming, so I know that there's a lot of volunteers out there who support a family with their own time, with their own resource, to make them feel more welcome."

Starting conversations is the aim of organisers at Bendigo's Refugee Week.

From multicultural storytime to school debates, 10 events will take place from June 17-23.

Christine Cummins, conveyor of Bendigo's Rural Australians for Refugees group is hoping the week will be a chance to promote harmony and inclusivity in the community.

"The purpose of the week is to really highlight the benefit of refugee settlement," she said.

"We have people from many different cultures that have settled in Bendigo and are continuing to settle in Bendigo, and they bring with them a wealth of wonderful knowledge and skills."

This year RAR has teamed up with other refugee advocacy and support groups to run its biggest program yet.

"It's really about trying to focus on getting people on board to recognise that people are people no matter where you come from," Ms Cummins said.

"Horrible things can happen to anyone, that hardship can be bombing, it can be any sort of persecution that makes people need to flee.

"When people have been forced to flee their homeland, they have really gone through a huge upheaval."

Refugee Week is important for communities like the Karen people, as a chance to honour their experience, Mr Aung said.

"We have many people who live in Bendigo who are of refugee backgrounds, and to celebrate something unique and important," Mr Aung said.

"It's not something to be ashamed of. We became refugees not because we chose to be, but due to our circumstances.

"Even though we escaped the refugee camp, we are no longer a refugee, it is also important to acknowledge our past and celebrate that, we are who we are because we are refugees. It made [us] who we are."

Currently studying a course in community service at at Bendigo Tafe, Mr Oo is looking to represent his community in the broader community of Bendigo.

He applied to be a fire officer trainee with DELWP as a step towards his goal of becoming a police officer.

His training will take two years, and probably see him move away from Bendigo's.

Now aged 18, Mr Oo's goal is to be a police officer by the time he turns 25.

"I want to be first Karen policeman in Bendigo," Mr Oo said.

"I want to work in my community, for my community. I want to represent for Karen people."

urn:contentItem:51N5-RV81-JD3N-502Y-00000-00Fire hero emerges2010-12-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:43:36ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. 20Fire hero emerges

THE worst forest fire in Israel's history has produced a new hero for the country a police chief hailed for her bravery and self-sacrifice in rushing into the flames to accompany rescuers.

The death yesterday of Police Chief Ahuva Tomer from her burns comes amid widespread Israeli anger and disappointment with their leaders' handling of the fire, which took 42 lives and burned half of one of the country's most popular forests.

Ms Tomer's patrol car was engulfed by flames minutes after she was interviewed on national TV in one of the iconic images of the five-day saga.

Late yesterday, police announced they had identified a 14-year-old boy as the ``prime suspect'' in the blaze. Authorities said the fire, all but extinguished on yesterday, was accidental.

Ms Tomer's ultimate sacrifice brought back images of a bygone era when leaders were seen as selfless heroes.

``Her last moment, when her car touched the fire, she looked out at us,'' President Shimon Peres said in a eulogy for Tomer. ``That's a moment none of us will forget . . . a high point in her bravery.''

Ms Tomer, 53, was following a bus of prison guards on their way to evacuate prisoners from a jail when her car and the bus were engulfed by the flames. Minutes later, Israeli media reported, a desperate Ms Tomer radioed to say she was on fire. Thirty-seven people on the bus were killed.

urn:contentItem:51MJ-GK01-F031-X1C1-00000-00Palestinian firefighters fight Israel blazes2010-12-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:43:36ZLexisNexisPalestinian firefighters fight Israel blazes

Palestinian firefighters have joined international efforts to put out the huge forest fire in northern Israel.

In a rare phone call on Saturday, the Israeli prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu thanked the Palestinian president Mahmoud Abbas for his support.

Meanwhile, the Israeli authorities say that it may take up to a week to put out the fire and a number of countries have been helping tackle the blaze.

"There are three Russian aircrafts that are working in the area," said Israeli police spokesman, Mickey Rosenfeld.

"There is also a further six airplanes on the way to here, to Israel, from the international support and community, including France and the United States, Spain, CyprusItaly and Hungary.

"All of this is in order to prevent the fires from spreading and to take control of the situation as quickly as possible."

At least 10 foreign firefighting planes have been flown to Israel to help control the massive bushfires that killed about 40 prison guards.

The guards were on their way to evacuate the Damon Prison in the Carmel mountains in northern Israel when their bus became trapped in the inferno after a burning tree fell across the road.

Some died inside the vehicle while 14 bodies were found on the ground outside.

Some of the men were apparently young cadets and trainees on one of their first big jobs.

The fire is still raging across Mt Carmel, which sits above the northern coastal town of Haifa.

urn:contentItem:51MW-DDM1-F0JP-W4RR-00000-00Inferno kills 402010-12-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:43:36ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. 28Inferno kills 40ISREAL Megadim, Friday

DOZENS of Israeli guards trying to rescue prisoners threatened by the worst forest fire in the country's history died when their bus became trapped in the same inferno.

The fire tore through a forest near Haifa in northern Israel on Thursday, prompting urgent calls for international help to tackle the blaze as it continued to burn out of control.

Magen David Adom (MDA) ambulance service confirmed it had recovered the bodies of 40 people who died in the inferno.

``Most of the dead were on board the bus,'' MDA spokesman Zachi Heller said, referring to the coach carrying the prison guards.

As the guards raced toward the prison holding mostly Palestinians, a tree fell across the road, blocking their path.

With no way out, many of them were burned alive inside the vehicle. Others perished while trying to flee the flames.

Rescue workers were still searching for an unspecified number of people, among them at least two police officers listed as missing, presumed dead.

Visiting the scene, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu described the tragedy as an ``unprecedented disaster''.

The flames forced 12,000 people from their homes, levelled a village and threatened to cause irreparable harm to one of Israel's few forested areas.

Twelve hours after the fire broke out, it was still raging out of control, with fire officials saying the inferno had incinerated at least 800 hectares of land.

Israel issued a rare call for international assistance.
