urn:contentItem:5VD0-P0Y1-F0J6-J0JY-00000-00Extreme heat driving our population to boiling point2019-02-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:43:36ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 20Extreme heat driving our population to boiling pointNiciole Hasham

Summer has changed, and so must we, writes Nicole Hasham.

Bela Stantic did not stop to take in the vistas of Walgett on his great Aussie road trip this summer. The vineyards of Griffith passed in a blur. He stopped at Victoria's Twelve Apostles, but took a few photos and left.

It was not what he had planned, but as a monster heatwave baked a crust onto southern Australia, "it was not possible to be outside at all". "I couldn't do anything, I was basically just in the car all the time," Stantic recalls.

"When I was planning the trip, Uluru was supposed to be 36 degrees. But when I got to Adelaide the weather prediction said it would be 46 degrees there ... I like warm weather but I thought 'this is extreme'."

Unhappy road trippers were not the only ones whose plans were disrupted by freakishly hot weather this summer. Sun melted a coastal highway in northern NSW. Victoria's coal generators shut down. Tasmania burned. And rotting fish lined the Darling River at Menindee.

The record-smashing temperatures have made it very clear: Summer has changed, and so must we.

"Climate change is putting stress on all our communities," says Sheila Nguyen, executive director of the Sports Environment Alliance. "We have to make decisions for the present and ... decisions for the future."

Western Sydney University researchers investigated the effect of high temperatures on city-dwellers. Their findings suggest summers are increasingly being lived indoors, in airconditioning - a trend that is making people more isolated and lonely.

"[On hot days] people would, if they had airconditioning at home, turn that on and stay within the home or get into an airconditioned car to go to an airconditioned shopping centre or cinema or other space," senior researcher Dr Louise Crabtree says.

Extreme heat can be crippling for those who can't cool their homes, such as people on low incomes.

"People in social housing can't put in an airconditioning unit or install a ceiling fan. They would literally lie on the floor in the coolest part of the house and not move for hours," Crabtree says.

Blast-furnace ambient temperatures also turn people off exercise. "If it's just too hot and a walk to the bus stop is too far and the bus stop has no shade, people will stop walking," Crabtree says.

Researchers are also concerned about the "mental health effects of feeling trapped in your house and unable to do anything about it".

The study suggested finding ways to cool outdoor urban spaces to draw people out of their homes, such as creating community gardens, as well as improving the accessibility of public infrastructure such as libraries, swimming pools and community centres.

A heavy reliance on airconditioners can also cause problems when the power bill arrives.

When Adelaide hit 46 degrees last month, making it the hottest capital city on record, pensioner Ann Petersen had to run her airconditioner day and night.

"It worries me because this is going to cost me a huge bill which I haven't budgeted for. And I know a lot of other people are going to be in exactly the same boat," the 71-year-old says.

Petersen, who manages a number of severe health conditions, found it extremely difficult to cope.

"I went out once to [get] the mail and I thought 'I'm going to pass out'," she says.

In a submission to a Senate inquiry last year, the Australian Medical Association said heatwaves kill more people than any other type of natural disaster. The elderly and the ill are especially vulnerable - a problem compounded by the ageing population.

The association cited "significant concerns" over the preparedness of the healthcare system to withstand the challenges of more frequent and severe extreme weather events.

Heatwaves cause a spike in ambulance callouts, hospital admissions and GP visits. A GP working in Sydney's west recounted a week in which she treated a warehouse worker who felt unwell after working in 40-degree temperatures, elderly patients with heat exhaustion from taking public transport and a patient with multiple sclerosis experiencing fatigue and difficulty walking.

Even the fittest among us are being forced to adapt to blistering temperatures. The Climate Council has warned extreme weather events threaten the viability of Australian sport as it is now played - from the elite level down to backyard cricket.

Heat affecting players and spectators at the Australian Open has become a perennial issue, and the opening stages of January's Tour Down Under cycling event were shortened amid predictions of temperatures above 40 degrees.

"We are restricted [as] to when we can play, when we can ride our bike, when we can go and play beach cricket," Nguyen says.

"All these things are changing the dynamic of the culture of sport, how we consume it and interact with it."

When summer gets unbearable, some might consider getting out of town. But Griffith University tourism expert Susanne Becken says extreme weather will change the way we holiday.

People will increasingly travel to beaches, lakes and swimming holes, or seek out the cooler temperatures of mountains and hinterlands. Traffic congestion in these places will increase, and emergency services can be stretched if, say, a bushfire arrives and thousands of people need to be evacuated.

Meantime, "people will avoid the hot places", Becken says. These include outback and regional areas where governments are investing in tourism infrastructure, she says, adding global warming was "in some ways undermining our economic development policies".

Storms, hail, smoke from bushfires and other extreme weather can disrupt flights, throwing holiday schedules into disarray.

And the pernicious effects of climate change can badly damage tourist attractions.

"The coral bleaching [on the Great Barrier Reef] is the most obvious. But also a forest fire in Tasmania - if the landscape is not as scenic or what you wanted to see is not there any more, that's obviously a longer-term problem," Becken says.

Bela Stantic has not given up on his road trip dreams. He wants to see the underground town of Coober Pedy and spend a New Year's Eve at Uluru. But in future he'll do it a little differently.

"Summer was not a good time to travel anywhere," he says. "Next time I'll do it in July."

urn:contentItem:5VCM-8HM1-JB75-932R-00000-00Climate change is poised to deliver more Black Saturdays in decades to come2019-02-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:43:36ZLexisNexisClimate change is poised to deliver more Black Saturdays in decades to comeScott Hamilton, Strategic Advisory Panel Member, Australian-German Energy Transition Hub, University of Melbourne

Black Saturday in 2009 was Australia's worst bushfire tragedy. But climate projections predict more bushfire danger in the future, threatening our water supplies as well as homes.

Ten years ago, on February 7, 2009, the Black Saturday bushfires killed 173 people. More than 2,000 houses were destroyed in Victoria, including at Kilmore, Kinglake, Vectis (Horsham), Narbethong, Marysville, Strathewan, Beechworth, Labertouche (Bunyip), Coleraine, Weerite, Redesdale, Harkaway, Upper Ferntree Gully, Maiden Gully, Bendigo, Eaglehawk, Lynbrook, St Andrews, Flowerdale, Narre Warren, Callignee, and my home town of Churchill, where my mother and father still lived. Their home wasn't burned, but many of their neighbours were badly affected by the worst bushfire day in Australia's history.

A week before, my uncle and aunt had to seek refuge at Mum and Dad's place when a fire ember landed in their front yard during the Boolarra bushfires. Mum has since passed and Dad still lives in Churchill.

The climate is changing due to human induced greenhouse gas emissions, and this means more bushfire danger days in what is already one of the most fire-prone countries in the world. Unfortunately, we have not done enough to curb climate change and the situation is getting worse.

Climate change means more days of extreme heat, longer heatwaves and more frequent droughts. Droughts now occur further south than in the past and have been increasing in Australia's southeast, including Tasmania. The records continue to tumble, and the evidence of dangerous climate change continues to mount.

Read more: Fires are increasing in warming world, but a new model could help us predict them

Back in 2008, John Brumby was Premier of Victoria and Kevin Rudd was Prime Minister. I was working on climate change for the Victorian government, developing projections for increased risk of bushfires. A 2005 study had already predicted an increase in fire weather risk throughout most of southeastern Australia over the coming decades, with "very high" and "extreme" fire danger ratings likely to increase in frequency by 4-25% by 2020 and 15-70% by 2050.

There has been more research in this area, although certainly not enough, given the huge stakes. A 2007 report for the Climate Institute of Australia predicted increases in annual average fire danger of up to 30% by 2050, and a potential trebling in the number of days per year where the uppermost values of the index are exceeded. The largest changes are predicted for the arid and semi-arid interior of New South Wales and northern Victoria.

The 2008 Garnaut Climate Change Review also warned that fire seasons will begin earlier, end slightly later, and generally be more intense. "This effect increases over time but should be directly observable by 2020," it said.

In 2015, a further study by CSIRO and the Bureau of Meteorology concluded that:

Projections of warming and drying in southern and eastern Australia will lead to increases in [forest fire danger index] and a greater number of days with severe fire danger. In a business as usual scenario (worst case, driest scenario), severe fire days increase by up to 160-190% by 2090.

By combining all of this research, I created the graph below.

This shows that while there is some uncertainty as to the extent of increase in the number of bushfire danger days in southeastern Australia, the situation is undoubtedly getting worse, and it's time for action.

In 2017, the independent Climate Council published a report on Victoria's growing bushfire threat, which made several stark findings and recommendations:

Climate change is increasing the risk of bushfires in Victoria and lengthening fire seasons.

Victoria is the state most affected by bushfires, and is on the front line of increasing bushfire risk.

The economic cost of bushfires in Victoria is an estimated A$180 million a year, and this is predicted to more than double by 2050.

Bushfires will continue to adversely affect human and environmental health.

In the future, Victoria is very likely to experience an increased number of days with extreme fire danger. Communities and emergency services across Victoria must be prepared.

Reducing greenhouse emissions is vital for protecting Australians.

Risk to water supplies

Our grandfathers and grandmothers had the wisdom to build amazing water infrastructure, protected by the "closed catchments" that give Melbourne and Victoria some of the best water in the world. Bushfires are a major risk to these water supplies - particularly in the catchments of major dams such as the Thomson.

A bushfire followed by a downpour that washes ash into the dam could potentially force the closure of the trillion-litre capacity Thomson reservoir, making it unusable for months. Firefighters have been battling exactly this kind of blaze at Mount Baw Baw in recent days and at the time of writing the situation has improved.

Major bushfires often occur in time of severe drought. Black Saturday itself happened towards the end of the 15-year Millennium Drought, when Victoria's water supplies were already strained. I remember vividly the then chief executive of the Melbourne Water Corporation urging the government to deal with any fire in the Thomson Dam catchment immediately, given the threat to Melbourne's water.

Fortunately, amid the devastation of Black Saturday we avoided major disruption to our water supplies. But this risk poses a huge challenge to both firefighters and policy-makers. The rule is that protection of human life is ranked above assets and infrastructure, and rightly so. But when there is a clear and present danger of towns and cities going without water, it's also true that safeguarding water means saving human lives in the ensuing days.

Read more: The bitter lesson of the Californian fires

Any way you look at it, these are hard questions. On our current trajectory, we are heading for terrible trade-offs.

In 2050 my daughter Astrid and my son Atticus - Mum and Dad's grandchildren - will be 45 and 43, respectively. I hope it is not too late for our leaders in Canberra, Davos and throughout the world to wake up and take urgent action to limit global warming 1.5?. That would mean that the most fearful predictions of our bushfire future never come to pass.

Scott Hamilton advises governments, businesses and communities on climate change, water and renewable energy. Scott is affiliated with H4 CO PTY LTD and is a panel member on the Australia-German Energy Transition Hub (hosted at University of Melbourne). Scott is also a member of the Australian Labor Party.

urn:contentItem:4P89-SH60-TXN5-V21V-00000-00Out now: Prozac for dogs and cats1999-03-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:43:36ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 6Out now: Prozac for dogs and catsSHORT ROUNDSJENNY DENNIS

It had to happen! Drug researchers in Switzerland have developed a Prozac-type drug for lonely cats and dogs.

The new drug - Clomipramine Hydrochloride - has just been launched in Australia and, yes, it's already a big hit in the United States.

Animal behaviourist Dr Kersti Seksel says the drug will help Puss and Rover with "anxiety-related conditions such as obsessive-compulsive disorder and separation anxiety".

Bet you didn't know our furry friends suffered obsessive-compulsive disorder, did you?

Dr Seksel says 17 per cent of dogs excessively bark, whine or howl, six per cent soil the house, 15 per cent chew, 21 per cent dig frantically and 13 per cent attempt to escape ... when they're left alone. Urine spraying and overgrooming is reported in about 10 per cent of cats left alone.

Clomipramine - a product developed by Novartis Animal Health - is available by veterinary prescription and is only for dogs and cats. We human obsessive-compulsives distressed at being alone will have to stick with Prozac or booze.

***

Stand back. The pistachio push has begun at Coles Warrawong, with staff reporting customers "going nuts" in the aisles.

Apparently the aroma of fresh Australian pistachios wafting out from the store's fresh produce section has sent its normally well-behaved customers into a frenzy.

Maybe it's because word has spread that one of Australia's leading nutritionists, Rosemary Stanton, recently recommended the little green nuts in the hard shell for anyone interested in a healthy diet.

"One major study reported that vegetarians who ate nuts more than four times a week had only half as many heart attacks as vegetarians who rarely ate nuts," Ms Stanton said.

She said many people were unaware that pistachios provided vitamins B1, B3 and vitamin E, plus minerals, anti-oxidants, mono-unsaturated oils and had absolutely no cholesterol. Also, the home-grown variety were dry-roasted and only lightly salted.

She forgot to add, they're also pretty yummy.

***

We feel we may have heard this one before, but urban myth or not, it's still a beauty ...

It seems fire authorities in California found a corpse in a burnt-out section of forest while assessing the damage done by a forest fire. The deceased male was dressed in a full wetsuit, complete with a dive tank, flippers, and face mask.

A post-mortem examination revealed that the person died not from burns but from massive internal injuries.

Dental records provided a positive identification and investigators then set about determining how a fully clad diver ended up in the middle of a forest fire.

They found that, on the day of the fire, the person went for a diving trip off the coast about 30km away from the forest.

The firefighters, seeking to control the fire as quickly as possible, called in a fleet of helicopters with very large buckets. The buckets were dropped into the ocean for rapid filling, then flown to the forest fire and emptied.

You guessed it. One minute our diver was making like Flipper in the Pacific, the next he was doing breaststroke in a fire bucket 100m in the air.

Some days it just doesn't pay to get out of bed.

***

Wollongong's Deputy Mayor has been knee-capped during a Wollongong City Council trip to Singapore ... but not in the political sense.

Councillor Vicky King swears her knee injury occurred during a corporate tug-of-war and who are we to doubt her?

The hobbling councillor returned to Wollongong on crutches yesterday, but won't be letting her injury stand in the way of her council responsibilities.

We're betting "tug-of-war" as a cause of injury will be a new one for the insurance assessors if Cr King puts in for workers' comp.

MONA VALE

Legal business

A FREE session on legal matters which affect businesses will be held at the Mona Vale Library on May 17 at 6.30pm. The session, titled Starting, protecting or controlling your small business, has been organised as part of Law Week. Mona Vale lawyer and Chamber of Commerce president Martin Alfonso will shed light on the legal system and what owners need to know about the law. Call 9970 1600 or book at the library, 1 Park St, Mona Vale.

FORESTVILLE

Annual cat show

THE Birman Cat Club of Australasia will host its 34th annual cat show at the Forestville Memorial Hall on May 22 from 10am to 4pm. The cats are known for their blue eyes, long hair and dark markings around their face and tail. The entry cost for adults is $5, $10 for a family and $2 for concessions. Kids under 12 can enter for free. A kiosk will be running on the day with tickets for the raffle purchased at the door.

DUFFYS FOREST

Orienteering courses

AN orienteering day has been organised in Duffys Forest on Sunday, May 22. Three different courses have been designed according to varying abilities and there are staggered starts between 10am and 11am, finishing about noon. The courses will start and finish at the Duffys Forest Fire Shed, Anembo Rd. There will be a sausage sizzle, food and drinks. The cost is $5 per entrant. Please note, no dogs are allowed. For more information about orienteering visit www.garingal.com.au. To RSVP, call Gwen laPointe on 9450 1226.

urn:contentItem:58YP-5741-JD34-V0RD-00000-00Forestry packages#nl#PORK-barr...2013-07-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:43:36ZLexisNexisPg. 17Forestry packages#nl#PORK-barr...Felicity Kirkpatric

Forestry packages

PORK-barrel heaven may be the best description of the forest compensation fiasco and no one should be surprised, least of all those most affected by the savaging of the forest industry and related businesses.

There is every probability that within a matter of a couple of years, maybe even a few months, most of the $90 million mentioned (The Examiner, July 8) will have disappeared into thin air.

Quite a chunk of it will go into what is referred to as ``administration costs", another large slice into newly constructed bureaucracies and the bit that's left will produce no meaningful benefit.

And unfortunately the idea that ``compensation" should apply to those most directly affected by this catastrophic forest ``fire" has already been shown to be fanciful with $10 million to the University of Tasmania for some obscure project despite there being very few forests in Sandy Bay or Newnham.

_ TREVOR G. COWELL, Perth.

Aboriginal heritage

HERITAGE Minister Brian Wightman says he will proceed with a new Aboriginal heritage bill, with or without Aboriginal approval.

The bill does not have broad Aboriginal support.

Through hard work, the Tasmanian ALP established a proud record on Aboriginal reconciliation over 20 years or so.

Whether in opposition or in government, the ALP always sought Aboriginal consent before tackling land or social issues.

The judicial father of native title, Sir Gerard Brennan, once said, ``The purpose of securing advancement for a racial group is not established by showing that the branch of government takes the measure for conferring what it regards as a benefit for the group if the group does not seek or wish to have the benefit. The wishes of the beneficiaries are of great importance (perhaps essential) in determining whether a measure is taken for securing their advancement. The dignity of the beneficiaries is impaired and they are not advanced by having an unwanted material benefit foisted on them".

The Giddings government is a miserable comparison of a once respected party.

_ MICHAEL MANSELL, Launceston.

urn:contentItem:548W-0871-F0N8-R3F0-00000-00Brett Worthington VICTORIA'S top2011-11-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:43:36ZLexisNexisPg. 1Brett Worthington VICTORIA'S topBrett Worthington

Brett Worthington VICTORIA'S top firefighter has warned Bendigo residents to get their houses in order as the city prepares to enter its fire danger period on December 5. The Country Fire Authority's chief officer Euan Ferguson visited Bendigo yesterday and announced the municipality's fire danger period start date alongside operations officer Mark Gilmore. Mr Ferguson offered a blunt assessment of the city's fire risk and said people only needed to think back to Black Saturday to remember the consequences of fire. He said he feared complacency was engulfing the community ahead of the year's fire risk period.

"We are concerned about complacency and I am being kind when I say complacency," he told the Bendigo Advertiser. "I think people are just apathetic. We have got excellent tools with the bushfire survival plan, but only about a quarter of people have filled out these forms. "That means 75 per cent are just not making use of the tools available." The City of Greater Bendigo will enter its fire danger period at 1am on December 5. The region has an above-average risk of grassfire this year but Mr Gilmore said the risk of forest fire was ever present. He urged people to put their angle grinders away until next year, with sparks from the equipment notorious for starting fires. "We are telling people to kiss their angle grinder goodbye and put it away until autumn," he said. "And don't let your lawnmower sun bake | only use it until 10am." During fire danger periods, there is a general prohibition on lighting fires unless a permit has been issued or, subject to conditions, the fire is for warmth or cooking. Continued | Page 6

urn:contentItem:5FCF-HS21-JD3N-52DR-00000-00How to host a dinosaur2015-02-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:43:36ZLexisNexisLIFESTYLEPg. 61How to host a dinosaurSimon Plant

SINKING his arm into a pile of prehistoric poo, Andrew Blackman always comes up with what he's searching for - a belly laugh.

"Works every time," the Australian-born actor says of his monster dung moment in Walking With Dinosaurs.

But Blackman, playing Huxley the palaeontologist in the arena spectacular, is always on message - even when he flicks the switch to vaudeville.

Like the show itself, a crafty blend of information and entertainment, he's full of facts and they need to be shared as wide-eyed audiences journey with him through the history of the world.

"It's great to have five thousand people with you and cheering those moments they identify with," Blackman says. Those moments can be intimate - a poo inspection, a mother dinosaur protecting her young - or something seismic - an erupting volcano, a forest fire, the formation of an ocean.

Huxley - the show's Indiana Jones-style narrator - is even on hand to observe continents splitting apart and massive comets hitting Earth.

"You can't really enter this world," he explains. "You need to run that fine line between focusing the audience's attention on these amazing creatures that are happening but never actually touching a dinosaur." Lanky actor Bruce Spence originated the role of Huxley when Walking With Dinosaurs stomped through Australian cities in 2007. Blackman signed on in 2011, when the show returned here, and has just completed a huge North American tour. This actor from Fitzroy has a long list of TV credits (most recently House Husbands, Dr Blake Mysteries and Underbelly: Squizzy).

But Blackman's long involvement with the Complete Works Theatre Company, a theatre-in-education outfit based at Abbotsford Convent, makes him especially suited to the "infotainment" demands of Walking With Dinosaurs.

"Huxley is the conduit, the link for the audience to this lost world," he explains. Blackman comes well armed with facts and figures but the narrative is leavened with comic asides.

"I do think of people like David Attenborough and the late Steve Irwin," he says. "Great communicators, both of them. Huxley, like them, is an expert who loves what he does. And my feeling is, if I'm excited by what's happening on stage, then the audience will suspend their disbelief." When the journey ends, in a cataclysmic blaze of sound and light, Huxley is still standing ... and taking his bow with a baby T-Rex.

"Yeah, it's a bit of showbiz," he says. "We take the work very seriously but we don't take ourselves too seriously."Walking With Dinosaurs The Arena Spectacular runs at Hisense Arena from March 25-29. Bookings: ticketek.com.au or 132 849

urn:contentItem:58NC-JHS1-JD3N-5520-00000-00Fatal fires lash Colorado2013-06-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:43:36ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. 37Fatal fires lash Colorado

United States, Los Angeles, Friday

TWO people have died while trying to flee a wildfire in Colorado that has burned down 360 homes, in the western US state's most destructive blaze, officials say.

About 38,000 people have been ordered to leave their homes as the blaze reached the edge of Colorado Springs, but officials voiced hope as the numbers of homes destroyed

and evacuations did not grow during the day.

The Black Forest fire, which broke out on Tuesday, was described as 5 per cent contained by Thursday afternoon, up from zero contained at the start of the day.

The two victims were found near their car in a heavily wooded area, and appeared to have been trying to pack belongings and flee when

they were overtaken by the flames, El Paso County Sheriff Terry Maketa said.

``It appears as though the individuals were in the garage, the car doors were open, as though they were loading or grabbing last-minute things,'' he said.

``All indications are . . . that they were planning to depart very quickly. When we get a fire and it's being carried by the winds, and it can jump from tree to tree, it can be very

deadly - and move very quickly.''

He gave no updated figure for the number of homes destroyed, which was given as 360 Thursday morning.

``I am very hopeful that we didn't lose any homes today,'' he said.

``That would be a huge victory. If we did lose any it was very few.''

The fire - the worst of several blazes ravaging the state - has forced the evacuation of 13,000 homes covering more than 6000ha. It was been fanned by high temperatures, dry conditions and strong winds.

About 750 firefighters are involved in battling the blaze, helped by federal authorities with resources including two C-130 aircraft, the Department of Defence announced.

The blaze is more destructive than last year's Waldo Canyon fire west of Colorado Springs, which burned 347 homes to the ground.

urn:contentItem:541Y-F881-F0JP-W4B5-00000-00Grassfire threat high in suburbs2011-10-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:43:36ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1Grassfire threat high in suburbsLand| Melissa Merrett

WHITTLESEA firefighters are warning residents to be on alert ahead of a potentially high-risk fire season.

While heavy winter rains were a welcome sight, they have encouraged extensive fire fuel growth.

Doreen CFA captain Chris Maries urged householders and landowners to be vigilant in the lead-up to summer.

``In Whittlesea there are lots of expanses of grass in and around the new suburbs,'' Mr Maries said.

``In general, grassfires are, and have been, very dangerous and we need to be vigilant as it is a different season to that of the forest fire season.

``It doesn't take long for grass to dry out.''

Fire Services Commissioner Craig Lapsley said the community should take note of the fire danger prognosis, even though the fire season was yet to be declared.

``It is early to be definitive about our summer fire conditions, however, early indicators shouldn't be ignored,'' Mr Lapsley said.

``Following the heavy rains last summer, and a drier than usual August, it is clear that this summer, there is a potential for large grassfires and when there is more grass, you have fires that can burn hotter and faster.''

Six of the 15 Northern Western Metropolitan Region Whittlesea Community Fire Ready Victoria meetings will be held at:

SOUTH Morang fire station, 875 Plenty Rd, on Thursday, October 27 at 7.30pm;

HAWKSTOWE Pde, Mernda, (opposite Hutmil Drive) on Friday, November 11, 7.30pm;

KALKALLO fire station, 661 Donnybrook Rd, on Monday, November 14, at 7.30pm;

BEVERIDGE community hall, Lithgow St, on Wednesday, November 23 at 7.30pm;

EDEN Park fire station on Friday, November 25, at 7.30pm; and,

THE intersection of 12th Ave and 13th Ave, Eden Park, on Friday, December 1, at 7.30pm.

Details: cfa.vic.gov.au

urn:contentItem:54GM-7551-JD6G-422R-00000-00Food and family fun at Mamre2011-10-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:43:36ZLexisNexisNEWS - GENERALFood and family fun at MamreKylie Stevens

Mamre Homestead transforms into a foodies paradise on Sunday for the Mamre Good Living Festival.

Now in its 22nd year, what started off as a garage sale and art/craft show has grown into a food and wine festival and is now part of the Crave Sydney International Food Festival.

More than 5000 attended last year's festivities.

Mamre development worker Sharon Holstein promises a great family day out with food produce stalls, wine tastings, pony rides, arts/crafts, children's activities and live entertainment.

Turkish and Asian food cuisine, Belgium waffles, Devonshire tea and a barbecue will offer a tasty feast of the world.

Proceeds go towards continuing the Mamre Project helping African refugees, young people and jobseekers.

ABC Radio 702 presenter Simon Marnie will broadcast his show live from Mamre Homestead.

Costa Georgiadis from SBS show Costa's Garden Odyssey will also be there.

The pair will return to Mamre on October 30 for the 100 Mile Dinner.

The theme of this year's dinner is Forest, Fire and Drums and is also part of the Crave Sydney International Food Festival.

Mt Druitt TAFE hospitality students will serve guests and prepare dessert on the night.

''It's about eating fresh, local produce sourced from a 160 kilometre radius,'' Ms Holstein said.

''Being part of Crave means we can attract people from outside the local area.''

100 Mile Dinner tickets are $100, which includes three courses, beer, wine and soft drinks.

Admission for Sunday is $3 adults, children free. Details:96705321.

Mamre Good Living Festival this Sunday, 9.30am-3.30pm at 181 Mamre Road, St Marys.

urn:contentItem:5BCN-6MC1-JCBD-909B-00000-00Battling blazes still a passion2014-01-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:43:36ZLexisNexisAPg. 7Battling blazes still a passionThe Chronicle

HE HAS spent more than 20 years volunteering for the ACT Rural Fire Service and last week Southern brigade deputy captain David Pennock returned from yet another inferno.

Mr Pennock is part of a vast army of volunteer firefighters that form eight brigades across the territory.

It is an organisation that has helped protect the Canberra region from severe bushfires for more than 50 years.

Most recently they helped their NSW colleagues prevent a major bushfire from getting into the vast pine plantations near Tumut, a region that has suffered terribly from bushfires in the past 10 years.

“If it went wrong the dangers were quite considerable," Mr Pennock said. “A pine forest fire is a very different beast to an open grass land fire. The conditions there are extremely dry and extremely unfavourable at times."

He joined the RFS in the early 1990s, at a time when Canberra had acres of pine plantations to its west and the Brindabellas could be mistaken for parts of British Columbia after heavy snow falls.

“I joined because I just wanted to find something interesting and challenging and to develop new skills," Mr Pennock said. “You're giving back to the community and I've seen some extremely interesting things.

“Some fires - although horrific - out in open mountain ranges are incredibly beautiful. I probably shouldn't say beautiful but they are just awe inspiring at night."

As the sun went down last week the fires reminded him of the scenes around Canberra more than 10 years earlier. It was then that fires wiped out the pine forests and destroyed hundreds of homes.

“You get to see things that not everyone gets to see," Mr Pennock said.

Volunteering remains a passion for him. And there are no plans to pull the pin on a job that has given him so many powerful experiences - both good and bad.

These include witnessing devastation to people and property, working with highly professional colleagues flying helicopters and operating heavy machinery in dangerous situations and witnessing extraordinary firestorms at night.

“It is just something that I do," he said.

“Everybody has different interests in their life.

I'm very well supported by my work and I think they see the value of volunteering."

urn:contentItem:4KN6-N5C0-TX52-M24V-00000-00BORING BUT IMPORTANT2006-08-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:43:36ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 10BORING BUT IMPORTANT

CAMEROON RECLAIMS PENINSULA

NIGERIA handed over the northern part of the Bakassi peninsula to Cameroon today after pulling out thousands of troops from the territory in line with an international ruling.

The International Court of Justice decreed in 2002 that Nigeria should turn over Bakassi, which has offshore oil deposits, to its eastern neighbour.

The Nigerian flag was lowered and that of Cameroon hoisted in Archibong, the capital of Bakassi, at a ceremony marking the formal handover.''We resolve to prevent the dispute over Bakassi from developing into war,'' Nigeria's Justice Minister Bayo Ojo said.

MORE PHOTOS PROMOTE CASTRO

A STATE-run Cuban paper today published pictures of Fidel Castro, showing the ailing communist in bed, receiving his brother Raul and Venezuelan President Hugo Chavez.

Publication of eight photos, taken on Castro's 80th birthday, marked the second time in two days Cuban media printed pictures of the president.

He hasn't been seen in public since before July 31, when it was announced he had undergone surgery.

ANTI-SMOKING LAWS KICK IN

MILLIONS of Chileans will now take their cigarette breaks outside, after a national anti-smoking law took effect today.

The measure, which bans smoking in schools, hospitals, government offices, stadiums, buses and public places, aims to cut an annual rate of 14,000 tobacco-related deaths in the country of 15.5 million people. The Health Ministry estimates 42 per cent of Chileans smoke. Smoking will be restricted in restaurants, with eateries given until May 2007 to create non-smoking sections. Smokers who light up face fines of $39.20.

POLICE SEIZE SATELLITE DISHES

IRAN launched a crackdown against ''decadent'' satellite television in the Islamic republic, raiding rooftops in Tehran.

The action came after a warning issued last month by Tehran's police chief to the 3-4 million satellite TV watchers who defy the law. ''The use of satellite dishes is prohibited by law and we ask people not to use this equipment,'' Morteze Talaie said. Police armed with warrants raided rooftops of large apartment blocks and high-rises in the chic northern and western areas of Tehran on Sunday.

FOREST FIRE THREATENS RESORT

A LARGE forest fire broke out near the summer resort of Saint Tropez today, reaching several millionaire's villas and evacuating 3000 people, French authorities said.

The seat of the blaze was at Ramatuelle, just 5km from the French Riviera town. Flames spread quickly due to a violent wind. A holiday camp housing 1000 people and a campsite with 900 residents had to be evacuated.

A beach popular with stars was under a dark cloud of smoke, visible 100km away in Nice, authorities said.

RECONCILIATION WREATHS LAID

GERMANY has commemorated the moment 45 years ago, when communist border guards threw up a barbed wire fence that was to evolve into the Berlin Wall and prevent millions of East Germans leaving for the west.

German Interior Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble and Berlin Mayor Klaus Wowereit laid wreaths at the main Wall memorial after an ecumenical religious service in the Chapel of Reconciliation at the site yesterday.

urn:contentItem:5V6G-RPH1-JD34-V0PP-00000-00Benloch fire contained and under control2019-01-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:43:36ZLexisNexisBenloch fire contained and under control

FOR EMERGENCY ADVICE: CLICK HERE

Update 9.51pm:

FIREFIGHTERS are confident they will be able to keep a fire at Benloch contained, despite the promise of another day of extreme weather conditions.

The maximum temperature in nearby Kyneton is forecast to be 38 degrees tomorrow.

Incident Controller John Pearce said the main work before nightfall today was to strengthen the control lines around the fire with mineral earth breaks.

He said crews would be working through the night to ensure the fire was safe.

"We're confident crews will be able to keep the fire within the fire lines," Mr Pearce said.

A wind change posed challenges for crews at the height of the firefight, causing the fire to jump a containment line.

But the most recent advice message from the CFA this evening stated there was no threat to residents of Benloch and nearby Nulla Vale, Baynton and Pastoria East, and traffic management points had been removed.

Incident Controller John Pearce praised today's firefighting efforts, which involved almost 50 CFA appliances, 10 Forest Fire Management Victoria units and seven aircraft, with assistance from a number of bulldozers and graders.

At its peak, the blaze posed a threat to homes and lives. The nearest property was 500 metres from the fire.

Nearby residents were told it was too late to leave and advised the safest option was to take shelter indoors immediately.

The fire, which started about 1pm, was contained and declared under control by about 3.50pm.

Mr Pearce said the reported only property losses related to fencing.

There were no reported injuries, and no assets lost.

"From our point of view it as a good fire fight," Mr Pearce said.

Today was a day of Total Fire Ban across Victoria, prompting a reminder from the CFA to have bushfire survival kits ready.

Tomorrow has not been declared a day of Total Fire Ban, though the fire conditions in both the Northern Country and North East districts are rated 'severe'.

The fire danger in the North Central, Wimmera and Mallee districts is 'very high', while a 'high' fire danger rating has been given to all other districts - including the central district, encompassing Kyneton.

The temperature in Bendigo is expected to reach a peak of 43 degrees tomorrow with light winds in the middle of the day and into the evening.

Tomorrow's forecast for Redesdale is similar, with the Bureau of Meteorology predicting: 'winds southerly 15 - 20km/h tending west to southwesterly 15 - 25km/h in the middle of the day then tending south to southeasterly in the evening."

The mercury in Castlemaine is expected to peak at 41 degrees, while temperatures in Maryborough are expected to reach a top of 42 degrees.

Kyabram's forecast maximum temperature is 45 degrees, while Echuca's is 46.

Police are still investigating the cause of the Benloch bushfire.

Investigators have urged anyone with information to contact Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000.

Firefighters also responded to a grass fire at Hylands Lane in Heathcote today.

The fire was not deemed to be a threat to nearby residents and was declared safe just before 7.30pm.

UPDATE 8.52pm: The CFA has downgraded the threat to residents in areas surrounding the Benloch fire from watch and act to advice.

Firefighters will remain at the fire ground overnight to ensure the fire is safe.

UPDATE 4.15pm:â€‹ A fire at Benloch has been contained and crews are working to build containment lines, to stop the fire moving further.

Five aircraft are responding to the fire, and 37 fire trucks are on the scene.

The CFA has warned that people still at home should leave now.

UPDATE 3.50pm: The fire is now contained and under control.

UPDATE 3.30pm: There have been 20 bush, grass and scrub fires across the state since midnight - with a 'disturbing trend' where many were connected to campfires.

UPDATE 3.15pm: A Vic Emergency media briefing is under way.

The most recent information is that the fire started about 1pm, and 'significant resources' have been sent to fight the fire - including six helicopters and an aircrane.

It is unclear how the blaze broke out.

Residents in the Kitchenhams Road area have been told to take shelter.

Emergency Management Commissioner Andrew Crisp says the state is putting "every asset possible" into the firefighting efforts.

"For those people in that area, I want to reassure you that we are doing everything possible in relation to that fire,'' he said.

"Because we don't have fires in any other parts of the state, we can throw as many assets as we can at this particular fire.

"We want to pull it up as soon as we can.''

The closest property is 500 metres from the fire, and while he says there is not a significant number of houses in the area, it was important to issue an emergency warning.

"Today is a spike day for us ... no one can become complacent.''

Mr Crisp says the three Ps are critical at this time of year - prepare, plan and public information.

UPDATE 2.55pm: Up to 50 vehicles are responding to an out of control fire at Benloch.

EARLIER: AN out of control fire is threatening homes and lives at Benloch.

The Country Fire Authority has issued an emergency warning, as a fire that started on Kitchenhams Road spreads quickly.

The CFA says the fire is threatening homes and lives.

The warning reads: 'you are in danger and need to act immediately to survive. The safest option is to take shelter indoors immediately. It is too late to leave.'

Firefighting aircraft have been called in to assist.

Here is the advice issued for those living in the area.

Today is a day of Total Fire Ban across Victoria and the CFA warned bushfire survival kits should be ready.

Severe fire conditions have been declared for the northern country district, which encompass Bendigo as well as areas north to Echuca.

It has also been declared in the north central district, which covers Castlemaine, Redesdale and Maryborough.

The fire weather warning comes with advice to people in high fire danger areas to monitor the weather and finalise plans.

urn:contentItem:7X8T-RPH1-2PW5-F1VM-00000-00Qld: Soaring heat and severe fire danger forecasted for Qld2009-12-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:43:36ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSQld: Soaring heat and severe fire danger forecasted for QldBRISBANE Dec 10

  The Bureau of Meteorology (BoM) has forecast severe grassland and forest fire danger for the Darling Downs and Granite Belt district.


   Temperatures of up to 42 degrees with relative humidity down to 15 per cent are forecasted for the region on Thursday.
   A Department of Community Safety (DCS) spokesman also said they were expecting 30km/h northwest to northeast winds.
   Brian Rolstone from the Bureau of Meteorology said temperatures in the interior west region were forecast to reach above 40 degrees again on Thursday.
   Meanwhile, firefighters have contained a large grass fire at Hillview in the Gold Coast hinterland.
   Two sheds and some fences were destroyed by the fire which started around 3.15pm (AEST) on Wednesday.
   The fire is now burning within containment lines and at this stage no property is under threat.
   The DCS spokesman said firefighters on the Atherton Tablelands in north Queensland had also contained a blaze which threatened houses, destroyed a shed and burnt a mango plantation on Wednesday afternoon.
   The dangerous fire conditions across the state have prolonged fire bans in Toowoomba, Southern Downs, Western Downs and Goondiwindi.
   Queensland Fire and Rescue Service has also extended the fire bans in the local government areas of Rockhampton, Banana, Gladstone, Bundaberg, North Burnett, Fraser Coast, Cherbourg. Whitsunday and South Burnett and Gympie.
   Fire bans will remain in place for these areas until December 14.

CRASH KILLS TWO

VICTORIA, British Columbia: Two pilots were confirmed dead yesterday in the crash of a Canadian water-bombing plane that was fighting a forest fire.

The wildfire and steep terrain kept rescue workers from reaching the crash site after the plane went down on Saturday night about 160 km northeast of Vancouver.

The plane, carrying two pilots, was chartered by the provincial government from Conair.

TENSE SITUATION

BOGOTA: Colombia increased security nationwide after leftist rebels on Sunday killed three off-duty soldiers, amid high tensions with Venezuela just days before a new president takes office in Bogota.

Colombia and neighbouring Venezuela broke off diplomatic ties after Bogota accused Caracas of harbouring thousands of leftist Colombian guerillas.

MAO PROMOTED

BEIJING: The grandson of Mao Zedong, the revolutionary leader who established the People's Republic of China in 1949, has been promoted to major general in the nation's army, state media said yesterday.

Mao Xinyu, a 40-year-old politician and researcher at the Academy of

Military Sciences of the People's Liberation Army, received the promotion ahead of the 83rd anniversary of the PLA's founding on Sunday, the Global Times said.

HAMAS WARNED

JERUSALEM: Israel's prime minister issued a stern warning yesterday to Gaza's Hamas rulers after a weekend of rocket attacks from the Palestinian territory on Israeli communities.

Benjamin Netanyahu told his Cabinet that Israel holds the Islamic militant group responsible for the rare flare-up in violence and would retaliate for any attack against its people.

urn:contentItem:4P3V-PV60-TXN5-S2XD-00000-00Need for the facts to fight deadly fires2007-01-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:43:36ZLexisNexisNEWSOpinionPg. 11Need for the facts to fight deadly firesATHOL HODGSON

Someone needs to sort out the mess in the fire management system.

GAVIN McFadzean of the Wilderness Society ("Trees don't start fires", Opinion 27/12) peddles fiction as fact, a mass of half-truths, pseudo-scientific lies and emotional blackmail to suggest that anyone who criticises the fire management of our national parks is anti-national park and pro-logging.

Members of Forest Fire Vic together have 400 years of combined experience in forest management, fire control and research. We are a group of professional forest practitioners and scientists formed after the disastrous 2002-03 Victorian bushfires. We don't argue cases for or against any particular use of forests for logging, grazing, parks or wilderness.

Forest Fire Vic is interested only in vastly improving fire management, regardless of what the forest is used for. We totally disagree with the contention that active management equates with a more fire-prone forest.

McFadzean relies on emotive and incorrect statements.

"Controlled burning can reduce fire hazard around towns and urban centres, but may also create a fire time bomb in the bush."

If controlled burning can reduce fire hazard in one place, it can do so elsewhere. Years of experience and research have shown that hazard reduction by burning makes firefighting safer and easier.

There is no evidence anywhere to support the contention that it creates a "time bomb in the bush".

"We need to remember that (national parks) are huge carbon sinks."

Forests, not national parks, are carbon sinks, and only then if they are actively growing. Some Victorian forests are huge carbon sources. There will be a permanent loss of carbon to the atmosphere if these forests are not regenerated.

"Their (forest ecosystems) response to regular hazard reduction burns is for fire-tolerant plants to take over from fire resistant plants . . ."

McFadzean does not explain the difference between a fire-tolerant plant and a fire-resistant plant. His implication is that fire-tolerant plants are more flammable and make the countryside more fire prone. All credible scientific evidence is that as fuels age after burning and build up to large quantities of litter, they become more hazardous - even after the pioneering plants have died out.

"Management burns are routinely made in most parks."

Not so, according to figures published in successive reports by the Auditor-General, the Esplin report into the 2003 bushfires, and Department of Sustainability and Environment reports. These all show the abject failure of Parks Victoria and DSE to achieve annual burning programs in any year, spanning two decades.

McFadzean cites the Esplin report on the 2002-2003 Victorian bushfires to argue that there are only about 10 days a year when conditions are right for prescribed burning. That argument comes from a desktop study done in the 1960s by Dr Malcolm Gill, who has no practical experience in prescribed burning and was co-author of the Esplin report.

It used Melbourne weather data and the ridiculous notion that prescribed burning could not be done at weekends, on public holidays and during the summer fire season.

DSE debunked that notion and now finds more days to do prescribed burning than it is able to take advantage of.

The real reasons DSE has not achieved its burning programs were identified after the fire in Wilsons Promontory National Park in 2005, in a second Esplin report.

Systemic and cultural shortcomings and the separation of entities such as Parks Victoria and VicForests from DSE disrupted the management of firefighting resources.

In short, DSE is dysfunctional and, with too few permanent staff accredited for fire-line work, is neither able to achieve its burning programs nor aggressively attack multiple fires in their incipient stages successfully.

Until someone sorts out the mess and makes the system work better, wilderness, national park and other forest values are doomed to degradation.

McFadzean also seems to know very little about the geography of Canberra or the fire that caused deaths and damage in 2003.

"The Canberra suburbs of Duffy and Curtin, which were razed in 2003, were surrounded by pine plantations and grasslands. Pine plantations are managed forests with plenty of roads and easy access, yet these forests created a firestorm".

The suburbs were not surrounded by plantations and grasslands but had sections with plantations, nature park and pasture on their western boundary.

A forensic analysis of the fire shows that the intensity of fires burning in the Namadgi and Brindabella national parks was so high that it created a tornado that carried fire 14 kilometres across eaten-out pasture and plantation alike, and the damage to the suburban houses was just as high where they were next to eaten-out pasture as where they were close to the plantation.

Victorians continue to pay too high a price for bushfires.

For what result? Built assets lost when bushfires burn with the wind and saved when the fires burn downhill or against the wind, water yields nearly halved for decades, millions of birds and mammals dead, forest diversity reduced and forests reduced from carbon sinks to carbon sources.

Melbourne Water is showing the way by recognising the importance of early detection and rapid, aggressive deployment of its highly skilled initial attack crews in protecting Melbourne's catchments.

Athol Hodgson is president of Forest Fire Victoria Inc, and a former chief fire officer of Victoria.
